The **history of the United States** began with the
[settlement](/wiki/Prehistoric_migration_and_settlement_of_the_Americas_from_Asia
"Prehistoric migration and settlement of the Americas from Asia") of
[Indigenous people](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States") before 10,000 BC. [Numerous
cultures](/wiki/Native_American_cultures_in_the_United_States "Native American
cultures in the United States") formed. The [arrival of Christopher
Columbus](/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus "Voyages of Christopher
Columbus") in 1492 started the [European colonization of the
Americas](/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas "European colonization
of the Americas"). Most colonies formed after 1600. By the 1770s, [thirteen
British colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") contained 2.5
million people along the [Atlantic
coast](/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United
States") east of the [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains
"Appalachian Mountains"). After [defeating
France](/wiki/French_and_Indian_Wars "French and Indian Wars"), the British
government imposed a series of new taxes after 1765, rejecting the colonists'
argument that new taxes needed their approval (see [Stamp Act
1765](/wiki/Stamp_Act_1765 "Stamp Act 1765")). Tax resistance, especially the
[Boston Tea Party](/wiki/Boston_Tea_Party "Boston Tea Party") (1773), led to
[punitive laws](/wiki/Intolerable_Acts "Intolerable Acts") by Parliament
designed to end self-government in Massachusetts.

Armed conflict began in 1775. In 1776, the [Second Continental
Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second Continental Congress")
declared a new, independent nation: the [United States of
America](/wiki/United_States_of_America "United States of America"). Led by
General [George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington"), it
won the [Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American
Revolutionary War") with large support from France. The [peace treaty of
1783](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1783\) "Treaty of Paris \(1783\)") gave the new
nation the land east of the Mississippi River (except [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada") and [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida")). The [Articles of
Confederation](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation")
established a central government, but it was ineffectual at providing
stability, as it could not collect taxes and had no executive officer. A
[convention](/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_\(United_States\) "Constitutional
Convention \(United States\)") in 1787 wrote [a new
Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
that was adopted in 1789. In 1791, a [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights") was
added to guarantee [inalienable rights](/wiki/Inalienable_rights "Inalienable
rights"). With Washington as the first president and [Alexander
Hamilton](/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton "Alexander Hamilton") his chief adviser, a
strong central government was created. [Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase
"Louisiana Purchase") of the [Louisiana Territory](/wiki/Louisiana_Territory
"Louisiana Territory") from France in 1803 doubled the size of the United
States. A second and final war with Britain was [fought in
1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812"), which solidified national pride.

Encouraged by the notion of [manifest destiny](/wiki/Manifest_destiny
"Manifest destiny"), U.S. territory expanded all the way to the [Pacific
coast](/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States "West Coast of the United
States"). While the United States was large in terms of area, [its
population](/wiki/Demography_of_the_United_States "Demography of the United
States") in 1790 was only 4 million. However this grew rapidly, reaching 7.2
million in 1810, 32 million in 1860, 76 million in 1900, 132 million in 1940,
and 321 million in 2015. Economic growth in terms of overall [GDP](/wiki/GDP
"GDP") was even greater. However compared to European powers, the nation's
military strength was relatively limited in peacetime before 1940. The
expansion was driven by a quest for inexpensive land for [yeoman](/wiki/Yeoman
"Yeoman") farmers and slave owners. The expansion of
[slavery](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States")
was increasingly controversial and fueled political and constitutional
battles, which were resolved by compromises. Slavery was abolished in all
states [north](/wiki/Northern_United_States "Northern United States") of the
[Mason–Dixon line](/wiki/Mason%E2%80%93Dixon_line "Mason–Dixon line") by 1804,
but the [South](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United States")
continued to profit off of the institution, mostly from [production of
cotton](/wiki/Cotton_production_in_the_United_States "Cotton production in the
United States"). [Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\)
"Republican Party \(United States\)") [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln
"Abraham Lincoln") was [elected in
1860](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1860 "United States
presidential election, 1860") on a platform of halting the expansion of
slavery.

Seven Southern slave states rebelled and created the foundation of the
[Confederacy](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of
America"). Its [attack of Fort Sumter](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter "Battle of
Fort Sumter") against the [Union forces](/wiki/Union_\(American_Civil_War\)
"Union \(American Civil War\)") started the [Civil
War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil War") (1861–1865). Confederate
defeat led to the impoverishment of the South and the abolition of slavery. In
the [Reconstruction Era](/wiki/Reconstruction_Era "Reconstruction Era")
(1863–1877), legal and voting rights were extended to [freed
slaves](/wiki/Freedmen "Freedmen"). The national government emerged much
stronger, and because of the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") in 1868, it gained
the explicit duty to protect individual rights. However, when white
[Democrats](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") regained their power in the South in 1877, often by
[paramilitary](/wiki/Paramilitary "Paramilitary") suppression of voting, they
passed [Jim Crow laws](/wiki/Jim_Crow_laws "Jim Crow laws") to maintain [white
supremacy](/wiki/White_supremacy "White supremacy"), and new
[disfranchising](/wiki/Disenfranchisement_after_the_Reconstruction_Era
"Disenfranchisement after the Reconstruction Era") constitutions that
prevented most [African Americans](/wiki/African_Americans "African
Americans") and many poor whites from voting. This continued until gains of
the [Civil Rights Movement](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement "Civil Rights
Movement") in the 1960s and passage of federal legislation to enforce
constitutional rights were made.

The United States became the world's leading industrial power at the turn of
the 20th century due to an outburst of entrepreneurship in the
[Northeast](/wiki/Northeastern_United_States "Northeastern United States") and
[Midwest](/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern United States") and the
arrival of millions of immigrant workers and farmers from
[Europe](/wiki/Europe "Europe"). The national railroad network was completed
and large-scale mining and factories industrialized the Northeast and Midwest.
Mass dissatisfaction with corruption, inefficiency and traditional politics
stimulated the [Progressive movement](/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive
Era"), from the 1890s to 1920s, which led to many reforms including the 16th
to 19th constitutional amendments, which brought the federal income tax,
direct election of Senators,
[prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition in the
United States"), and [women's
suffrage](/wiki/Women%27s_Suffrage_in_the_United_States "Women's Suffrage in
the United States"). Initially neutral during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I
"World War I"), the United States [declared war on
Germany](/wiki/American_entry_into_World_War_I "American entry into World War
I") in 1917 and funded the Allied victory the following year.

After [a prosperous decade](/wiki/Roaring_Twenties "Roaring Twenties") in the
1920s, the [Wall Street Crash of 1929](/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall
Street Crash of 1929") marked the onset of the decade-long worldwide [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_States "Great Depression in
the United States"). Democratic President [Franklin D.
Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") ended the
Republican dominance of the [White House](/wiki/White_House "White House") and
implemented his [New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") programs, which included
relief for the unemployed, support for farmers, [Social
Security](/wiki/Social_Security_\(United_States\) "Social Security \(United
States\)") and a [minimum wage](/wiki/Minimum_wage "Minimum wage"). The New
Deal defined [modern American liberalism](/wiki/Modern_American_liberalism
"Modern American liberalism"). After the [Japanese attack on Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor") in 1941, the
United States entered [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") and
financed the [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II")
war effort and helped defeat [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany")
in the [European theater](/wiki/European_Theatre_of_World_War_II "European
Theatre of World War II"). Its involvement culminated in using newly invented
[nuclear weapons on two Japanese
cities](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of
Hiroshima and Nagasaki") to defeat [Imperial Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan
"Empire of Japan") in the [Pacific theater](/wiki/Pacific_War "Pacific War").

The United States and the [Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union")
emerged as rival superpowers in the [aftermath of World War
II](/wiki/Aftermath_of_World_War_II "Aftermath of World War II"). During the
[Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), the two countries confronted each other
indirectly in the [arms race](/wiki/Arms_race "Arms race"), the [Space
Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), [proxy wars](/wiki/Proxy_war "Proxy
war"), and propaganda campaigns. The purpose of this was to stop the spread of
communism. In the 1960s, in large part due to the strength of the Civil Rights
Movement, another wave of social reforms was enacted by enforcing the
constitutional rights of voting and freedom of movement to African-Americans
and other racial minorities. The Cold War ended when the [Soviet Union was
officially dissolved](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of
the Soviet Union") in 1991, leaving the United States as the world's only
superpower.

After the Cold War, the United States began focusing on [modern conflicts in
the Middle East](/wiki/List_of_modern_conflicts_in_the_Middle_East "List of
modern conflicts in the Middle East") and [nuclear programs in North
Korea](/wiki/North_Korea_and_weapons_of_mass_destruction "North Korea and
weapons of mass destruction"). The beginning of the 21st century saw the
[September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks") by
[Al-Qaeda](/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-Qaeda") in 2001, which was later followed by the
U.S.-led wars in [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War") and
[Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%932014\) "War in
Afghanistan \(2001–2014\)"). In 2008, the United States had its [worst
economic crisis since the Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Recession_in_the_United_States "Great Recession in the
United States"), which was followed by slower-than-usual rates of economic
growth during the 2010s.

This map shows the approximate location of the ice-free corridor and specific
Paleoindian sites ([Clovis theory](/wiki/Clovis_theory "Clovis theory")).

It is not definitively known how or when the Native Americans first [settled
the
Americas](/wiki/Prehistoric_migration_and_settlement_of_the_Americas_from_Asia
"Prehistoric migration and settlement of the Americas from Asia") and the
present-day United States. The prevailing theory proposes that people migrated
from [Eurasia](/wiki/Eurasia "Eurasia") across [Beringia](/wiki/Beringia
"Beringia"), a [land bridge](/wiki/Land_bridge "Land bridge") that connected
[Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia") to present-day [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska
"Alaska") during the [Ice Age](/wiki/Quaternary_glaciation "Quaternary
glaciation"), and then spread southward throughout the Americas and possibly
going as far south as the [Antarctic Peninsula](/wiki/Antarctic_Peninsula
"Antarctic Peninsula").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] This migration may have begun as early as
30,000 years ago[1] and continued through to about 10,000+ years ago, when the
land bridge became submerged by the rising sea level caused by the ending of
the [last glacial period](/wiki/Last_glacial_period "Last glacial period").[2]
These early inhabitants, called [Paleoamericans](/wiki/Paleoamericans
"Paleoamericans"), soon diversified into many hundreds of culturally distinct
nations and tribes.

The pre-Columbian era incorporates all [period
subdivisions](/wiki/Archaeology_of_the_Americas "Archaeology of the Americas")
in the [history and prehistory of the Americas](/wiki/History_of_the_Americas
"History of the Americas") before the appearance of significant European
influences on the [American](/wiki/Americas "Americas") continents, spanning
the time of the [original settlement](/wiki/Migration_to_the_New_World
"Migration to the New World") in the [Upper
Paleolithic](/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic "Upper Paleolithic") period to [European
colonization](/wiki/European_colonization_of_the_Americas "European
colonization of the Americas") during the [early modern
period](/wiki/Early_modern_period "Early modern period"). While technically
referring to the era before [Christopher Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus
"Christopher Columbus")' voyages of 1492 to 1504, in practice the term usually
includes the history of [American indigenous
cultures](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the
Americas") until they were conquered or significantly influenced by Europeans,
even if this happened decades or even centuries after Columbus' initial
landing.

### Native development prior to European
contact[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Native development prior to European contact")]

Main article: [History of Native Americans in the United
States](/wiki/History_of_Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "History of
Native Americans in the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Nordamerikanische_Kulturareale_en.png/200px-
Nordamerikanische_Kulturareale_en.png)](/wiki/File:Nordamerikanische_Kulturareale_en.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nordamerikanische_Kulturareale_en.png "Enlarge")

The [Cultural areas](/wiki/Cultural_area "Cultural area") of [pre-Columbian
North America](/wiki/Pre-Columbian_North_America "Pre-Columbian North
America"), according to [Alfred Kroeber](/wiki/Alfred_Kroeber "Alfred
Kroeber").

Native American cultures are not normally included in characterizations of
advanced stone age cultures as "[Neolithic](/wiki/Neolithic "Neolithic"),"
which is a category that more often includes only the cultures in Eurasia,
Africa, and other regions. The [archaeological
periods](/wiki/List_of_archaeological_periods_\(North_America\) "List of
archaeological periods \(North America\)") used are the classifications of
archaeological periods and cultures established in [Gordon
Willey](/wiki/Gordon_Willey "Gordon Willey") and [Philip
Phillips](/wiki/Philip_Phillips_\(archaeologist\) "Philip Phillips
\(archaeologist\)")' 1958 book _Method and Theory in American Archaeology_.
They divided the archaeological record in the Americas into five phases;[3]
see [Archaeology of the
Americas](/wiki/Archaeology_of_the_Americas#Archaeological_time_periods
"Archaeology of the Americas").

The [Clovis culture](/wiki/Clovis_culture "Clovis culture"), a
[megafauna](/wiki/Megafauna "Megafauna") hunting culture, is primarily
identified by use of fluted [spear](/wiki/Spear "Spear") points. Artifacts
from this culture were first excavated in 1932 near [Clovis, New
Mexico](/wiki/Clovis,_New_Mexico "Clovis, New Mexico"). The Clovis culture
ranged over much of North America and also appeared in South America. The
culture is identified by the distinctive [Clovis point](/wiki/Clovis_point
"Clovis point"), a flaked flint spear-point with a notched flute, by which it
was inserted into a shaft. Dating of Clovis materials has been by association
with animal bones and by the use of [carbon dating](/wiki/Carbon_dating
"Carbon dating") methods. Recent reexaminations of Clovis materials using
improved carbon-dating methods produced results of 11,050 and 10,800
radiocarbon years [B.P.](/wiki/Before_Present "Before Present") (roughly 9100
to 8850 BCE).

Numerous [Paleoindian](/wiki/Paleoindian "Paleoindian") cultures occupied
North America, with some arrayed around the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains
"Great Plains") and [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") of the
modern [United States of America](/wiki/United_States "United States") and
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"), as well as adjacent areas to the West and
Southwest. According to the oral histories of many of the indigenous peoples
of the Americas, they have been living on this continent since their genesis,
described by a wide range of traditional [creation
stories](/wiki/Creation_stories "Creation stories"). Other tribes have stories
that recount migrations across long tracts of land and a great river, believed
to be the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River").[4]
Genetic and linguistic data connect the indigenous people of this continent
with ancient northeast Asians. Archeological and linguistic data has enabled
scholars to discover some of the migrations within the Americas.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Folsom_point.png)](/wiki/File:Folsom_point.png)

[](/wiki/File:Folsom_point.png "Enlarge")

A [Folsom point](/wiki/Folsom_point "Folsom point") for a spear.

The [Folsom Tradition](/wiki/Folsom_Tradition "Folsom Tradition") was
characterized by use of [Folsom points](/wiki/Folsom_point "Folsom point") as
projectile tips, and activities known from kill sites, where slaughter and
butchering of [bison](/wiki/Bison "Bison") took place. Folsom tools were left
behind between 9000 BCE and 8000 BCE.[5]

[Na-Dené](/wiki/Na-Dene_languages "Na-Dene languages")-speaking peoples
entered North America starting around 8000 BCE, reaching the [Pacific
Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest "Pacific Northwest") by 5000 BCE,[6] and
from there migrating along the [Pacific Coast](/wiki/Pacific_Coast "Pacific
Coast") and into the interior. Linguists, anthropologists and archeologists
believe their ancestors comprised a separate migration into North America,
later than the first Paleo-Indians. They migrated into Alaska and northern
Canada, south along the Pacific Coast, into the interior of Canada, and south
to the Great Plains and the American Southwest.

They were the earliest ancestors of the [Athabascan](/wiki/Athabascan
"Athabascan")\- speaking peoples, including the present-day and historical
[Navajo](/wiki/Navajo_people "Navajo people") and [Apache](/wiki/Apache
"Apache"). They constructed large multi-family dwellings in their villages,
which were used seasonally. People did not live there year-round, but for the
summer to hunt and fish, and to gather food supplies for the winter.[7] The
[Oshara Tradition](/wiki/Oshara_Tradition "Oshara Tradition") people lived
from 5500 BCE to 600 CE. They were part of the [Southwestern Archaic
Tradition](/wiki/Southwestern_Archaic_Traditions "Southwestern Archaic
Traditions") centered in north-central [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New
Mexico"), the [San Juan Basin](/wiki/San_Juan_Basin "San Juan Basin"), the
[Rio Grande](/wiki/Rio_Grande "Rio Grande") Valley, southern
[Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado"), and southeastern [Utah](/wiki/Utah
"Utah").

Since the 1990s, archeologists have explored and dated eleven Middle
[Archaic](/wiki/Archaic_period_in_the_Americas "Archaic period in the
Americas") sites in present-day Louisiana and Florida at which early cultures
built complexes with multiple [earthwork](/wiki/Earthworks_\(archaeology\)
"Earthworks \(archaeology\)") [mounds](/wiki/Mound "Mound"); they were
societies of hunter-gatherers rather than the settled agriculturalists
believed necessary according to the theory of [Neolithic
Revolution](/wiki/Neolithic_Revolution "Neolithic Revolution") to sustain such
large villages over long periods. The prime example is [Watson
Brake](/wiki/Watson_Brake "Watson Brake") in northern Louisiana, whose
11-mound complex is dated to 3500 BCE, making it the oldest, dated site in the
Americas for such complex construction. It is nearly 2,000 years older than
the [Poverty Point](/wiki/Poverty_Point "Poverty Point") site. Construction of
the mounds went on for 500 years until was abandoned about 2800 BCE, probably
due to changing environmental conditions.[8]

[Poverty Point culture](/wiki/Poverty_Point_culture "Poverty Point culture")
is a Late Archaic [archaeological culture](/wiki/Archaeological_culture
"Archaeological culture") that inhabited the area of the lower Mississippi
Valley and surrounding Gulf Coast. The culture thrived from 2200 BCE to 700
BCE, during the Late Archaic period.[9] Evidence of this culture has been
found at more than 100 sites, from the major complex at [Poverty
Point](/wiki/Poverty_Point "Poverty Point") (a [UNESCO](/wiki/UNESCO "UNESCO")
[World Heritage Site](/wiki/World_Heritage_Site "World Heritage Site")) across
a 100-mile (160 km) range to the [Jaketown Site](/wiki/Jaketown_Site "Jaketown
Site") near [Belzoni, Mississippi](/wiki/Belzoni,_Mississippi "Belzoni,
Mississippi").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Wrangell_totem_poles.JPG/200px-
Wrangell_totem_poles.JPG)](/wiki/File:Wrangell_totem_poles.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Wrangell_totem_poles.JPG "Enlarge")

Totem poles in [Wrangell, Alaska](/wiki/Wrangell,_Alaska "Wrangell, Alaska").

Poverty Point is a 1 square mile (2.6 km2) complex of six major earthwork
concentric rings, with additional platform mounds at the site. Artifacts show
the people traded with other Native Americans located from Georgia to the
Great Lakes region. This is one among numerous mound sites of complex
indigenous cultures throughout the Mississippi and Ohio valleys. They were one
of several succeeding cultures often referred to as [mound
builders](/wiki/Mound_builder_\(people\) "Mound builder \(people\)").

The [Woodland period](/wiki/Woodland_period "Woodland period") of [North
American](/wiki/North_America "North America") [pre-Columbian](/wiki/Pre-
Columbian "Pre-Columbian") cultures refers to the time period from roughly
1000 BCE to 1,000 CE in the eastern part of North America. The term "Woodland"
was coined in the 1930s and refers to prehistoric sites dated between the
[Archaic period](/wiki/Archaic_period_in_the_Americas "Archaic period in the
Americas") and the [Mississippian cultures](/wiki/Mississippian_culture
"Mississippian culture"). The [Hopewell tradition](/wiki/Hopewell_tradition
"Hopewell tradition") is the term for the common aspects of the Native
American culture that flourished along rivers in the northeastern and
midwestern [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") from 200 BCE
to 500 CE.[10]

The [indigenous peoples of the Pacific Northwest
Coast](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Pacific_Northwest_Coast "Indigenous
peoples of the Pacific Northwest Coast") were of many nations and tribal
affiliations, each with distinctive cultural and political identities, but
they shared certain beliefs, traditions and practices, such as the centrality
of [salmon](/wiki/Salmon "Salmon") as a resource and spiritual symbol. Their
gift-giving feast, [potlatch](/wiki/Potlatch "Potlatch"), is a highly complex
event where people gather in order to commemorate special events. These
events, such as, the raising of a [Totem pole](/wiki/Totem_pole "Totem pole")
or the appointment or election of a new chief. The most famous artistic
feature of the culture is the Totem pole, with carvings of animals and other
characters to commemorate cultural beliefs, legends, and notable events.

The Hopewell tradition was not a single [culture](/wiki/Culture "Culture") or
society, but a widely dispersed set of related populations, who were connected
by a common network of trade routes,[11] known as the Hopewell Exchange
System. At its greatest extent, the Hopewell exchange system ran from the
Southeastern [United States](/wiki/United_States "United States") into the
southeastern [Canadian](/wiki/Canada "Canada") shores of [Lake
Ontario](/wiki/Lake_Ontario "Lake Ontario"). Within this area, societies
participated in a high degree of exchange; most activity was conducted along
the waterways that served as their major transportation routes. The Hopewell
exchange system traded materials from all over the United States.

[Grave Creek Mound](/wiki/Grave_Creek_Mound "Grave Creek Mound"), located in
[Moundsville, West Virginia](/wiki/Moundsville,_West_Virginia "Moundsville,
West Virginia"), is one of the largest conical mounds in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States"). It was built by the [Adena
culture](/wiki/Adena_culture "Adena culture").

  * **[Adena culture](/wiki/Adena_culture "Adena culture")** : The Adena culture was a [Native American](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans in the United States") culture that existed from 1000 BC to 200 BC, in a time known as the [Early Woodland period](/wiki/Woodland_period#Early_Woodland_period_\(1000–1_BC\) "Woodland period"). The Adena culture refers to what were probably a number of related Native American societies sharing a burial complex and ceremonial system.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Coles_Creek_culture_map_HRoe_2010.jpg/200px-
Coles_Creek_culture_map_HRoe_2010.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coles_Creek_culture_map_HRoe_2010.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Coles_Creek_culture_map_HRoe_2010.jpg "Enlarge")

A map showing the extent of the Coles Creek cultural period and some important
sites.

  * **[Coles Creek culture](/wiki/Coles_Creek_culture "Coles Creek culture")** : The Coles Creek culture is an indigenous development of the Lower Mississippi Valley that took place between the terminal [Woodland period](/wiki/Woodland_period "Woodland period") and the later [Plaquemine culture](/wiki/Plaquemine_culture "Plaquemine culture") period. The period is marked by the increased use of flat-topped [platform mounds](/wiki/Platform_mound "Platform mound") arranged around central plazas, more complex political institutions, and a subsistence strategy still grounded in the [Eastern Agricultural Complex](/wiki/Eastern_Agricultural_Complex "Eastern Agricultural Complex") and hunting rather than on the [maize](/wiki/Maize "Maize") plant as would happen in the succeeding [Plaquemine Mississippian](/wiki/Plaquemine_Mississippian "Plaquemine Mississippian") period. The culture was originally defined by the unique decoration on [grog](/wiki/Grog_\(clay\) "Grog \(clay\)")-tempered ceramic ware by [James A. Ford](/wiki/James_A._Ford "James A. Ford") after his investigations at the [Mazique Archeological Site](/wiki/Mazique_Archeological_Site "Mazique Archeological Site"). He had studied both the Mazique and Coles Creek Sites, and almost went with the _Mazique culture_ , but decided on the less historically involved sites name. It is ancestral to the [Plaquemine culture](/wiki/Plaquemine_culture "Plaquemine culture").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/CasaGrandeRuin.jpg/200px-
CasaGrandeRuin.jpg)](/wiki/File:CasaGrandeRuin.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:CasaGrandeRuin.jpg "Enlarge")

The Great House at the [Casa Grande Ruins National
Monument](/wiki/Casa_Grande_Ruins_National_Monument "Casa Grande Ruins
National Monument").

  * **[Hohokam culture](/wiki/Hohokam "Hohokam")** : The Hohokam was a culture centered along [American Southwest](/wiki/American_Southwest "American Southwest").[12] The early Hohokam founded a series of small villages along the middle [Gila River](/wiki/Gila_River "Gila River"). They raised corn, squash and beans. The communities were located near good arable land, with [dry farming](/wiki/Dry_farming "Dry farming") common in the earlier years of this period.[12] They were known for their pottery, using the paddle-and-anvil technique. The Classical period of the culture saw the rise in architecture and ceramics. Buildings were grouped into walled compounds, as well as earthen platform mounds. Platform mounds were built along river as well as irrigation canal systems, suggesting these sites were administrative centers allocating water and coordinating canal labor. Polychrome pottery appeared, and inhumation burial replaced cremation. Trade included that of shells and other exotics. Social and climatic factors led to a decline and abandonment of the area after 1400 A.D.

  * **[Ancestral Puebloan culture](/wiki/Ancestral_Puebloan "Ancestral Puebloan")** : The Ancestral Puebloan culture covered present-day [Four Corners](/wiki/Four_Corners "Four Corners") region of the United States, comprising southern [Utah](/wiki/Utah "Utah"), northern [Arizona](/wiki/Arizona "Arizona"), northwestern [New Mexico](/wiki/New_Mexico "New Mexico"), and southwestern [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado").[13] It is believed that the Ancestral Puebloans developed, at least in part, from the [Oshara Tradition](/wiki/Oshara_Tradition "Oshara Tradition"), who developed from the [Picosa culture](/wiki/Picosa_culture "Picosa culture"). They lived in a range of structures that included small family pit houses, larger clan type structures, grand [pueblos](/wiki/Pueblos "Pueblos"), and cliff sited dwellings. The Ancestral Puebloans possessed a complex network that stretched across the [Colorado Plateau](/wiki/Colorado_Plateau "Colorado Plateau") linking hundreds of communities and population centers. The culture is perhaps best known for the stone and earth dwellings built along cliff walls, particularly during the [Pueblo II](/wiki/Pueblo_II_Era "Pueblo II Era") and [Pueblo III](/wiki/Pueblo_III_Era "Pueblo III Era") eras. 
    * Three [UNESCO World Heritage Sites](/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites "UNESCO World Heritage Sites") located in the United States are credited to the Pueblos: [Mesa Verde National Park](/wiki/Mesa_Verde_National_Park "Mesa Verde National Park"), [Chaco Culture National Historical Park](/wiki/Chaco_Culture_National_Historical_Park "Chaco Culture National Historical Park") and [Taos Pueblo](/wiki/Taos_Pueblo "Taos Pueblo").
    * The best-preserved examples of the stone dwellings are in [National Parks](/wiki/National_Parks "National Parks"), examples being, [Navajo National Monument](/wiki/Navajo_National_Monument "Navajo National Monument"), Chaco Culture National Historical Park, Mesa Verde National Park, [Canyons of the Ancients National Monument](/wiki/Canyons_of_the_Ancients_National_Monument "Canyons of the Ancients National Monument"), [Aztec Ruins National Monument](/wiki/Aztec_Ruins_National_Monument "Aztec Ruins National Monument"), [Bandelier National Monument](/wiki/Bandelier_National_Monument "Bandelier National Monument"), [Hovenweep National Monument](/wiki/Hovenweep_National_Monument "Hovenweep National Monument"), and [Canyon de Chelly National Monument](/wiki/Canyon_de_Chelly_National_Monument "Canyon de Chelly National Monument").

  * **[Mississippian culture](/wiki/Mississippian_culture "Mississippian culture")** : The Mississippian culture which extended throughout the Ohio and Mississippi valleys and built sites throughout the Southeast, created the largest [earthworks](/wiki/Earthworks_\(archaeology\) "Earthworks \(archaeology\)") in North America north of Mexico, most notably at [Cahokia](/wiki/Cahokia "Cahokia"), on a tributary of the Mississippi River in present-day Illinois. 
    * The ten-story [Monks Mound](/wiki/Monks_Mound "Monks Mound") at Cahokia has a larger circumference than the [Pyramid of the Sun](/wiki/Pyramid_of_the_Sun "Pyramid of the Sun") at [Teotihuacan](/wiki/Teotihuacan "Teotihuacan") or the [Great Pyramid](/wiki/Great_Pyramid_of_Giza "Great Pyramid of Giza") of [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt"). The 6 square miles (16 km2) city complex was based on the culture's cosmology; it included more than 100 mounds, positioned to support their sophisticated knowledge of [astronomy](/wiki/Astronomy "Astronomy"), and built with knowledge of varying soil types. The society began building at this site about 950 CE, and reached its peak population in 1,250 CE of 20,000–30,000 people, which was not equalled by any city in the present-day United States until after 1800.
    * Cahokia was a major regional [chiefdom](/wiki/Chiefdom "Chiefdom"), with trade and tributary chiefdoms located in a range of areas from bordering the [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") to the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico").
    * [Kincaid](/wiki/Kincaid_Mounds_State_Historic_Site "Kincaid Mounds State Historic Site")[14] c. 1050–1400 AD,[15] is one of the largest settlements of the Mississippian culture, it was located at the southern tip of present-day [U.S. state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S. state") of [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"). Kincaid Mounds has been notable for both its significant role in native [North American prehistory](/wiki/Precolumbian#North_America "Precolumbian") and for the central role the site has played in the development of modern [archaeological techniques](/wiki/Archaeology#Methods "Archaeology"). The site had at least 11 substructure [platform mounds](/wiki/Platform_mound "Platform mound") (ranking fifth for mound-culture pyramids). Artifacts from the settlement link its major habitation and the construction of the mounds to the Mississippian period, but it was also occupied earlier during the [Woodland period](/wiki/Woodland_period "Woodland period").
    * The Mississippian culture developed the [Southeastern Ceremonial Complex](/wiki/Southeastern_Ceremonial_Complex "Southeastern Ceremonial Complex"), the name which archeologists have given to the regional stylistic similarity of [artifacts](/wiki/Artifact_\(archaeology\) "Artifact \(archaeology\)"), [iconography](/wiki/Iconography "Iconography"), [ceremonies](/wiki/Ceremony "Ceremony") and [mythology](/wiki/Mythology "Mythology"). The rise of the complex culture was based on the people's adoption of [maize](/wiki/Maize "Maize") agriculture, development of greater population densities, and [chiefdom](/wiki/Chiefdom "Chiefdom")-level complex social organization from 1200 CE to 1650 CE.[16][17]
    * The [Mississippian pottery](/wiki/Mississippian_pottery "Mississippian pottery") are some of the finest and most widely spread ceramics north of [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). [Cahokian pottery](/wiki/Cahokian_pottery "Cahokian pottery") was especially fine, with smooth surfaces, very thin walls and distinctive tempering, slips and coloring.[18]

Map of the Five Nations of the [Iroquois](/wiki/Iroquois "Iroquois") (from the
[Darlington Collection](/wiki/Darlington_Collection "Darlington Collection")).

  * **[Iroquois Culture](/wiki/Iroquois "Iroquois")** : The [Iroquois League of Nations](/wiki/Iroquois "Iroquois") or "People of the Long House", based in present-day upstate and western [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), had a [confederacy](/wiki/Confederation "Confederation") model from the mid-15th century. It has been suggested that their culture contributed to political thinking during the development of the later United States government. Their system of affiliation was a kind of federation, different from the strong, centralized European monarchies.[19][20][21]
    * Leadership was restricted to a group of 50 [sachem](/wiki/Sachem "Sachem") [chiefs](/wiki/Tribal_chief "Tribal chief"), each representing one [clan](/wiki/Clan "Clan") within a tribe. The [Oneida](/wiki/Oneida_people "Oneida people") and [Mohawk people](/wiki/Mohawk_people "Mohawk people") had nine seats each; the [Onondagas](/wiki/Onondaga_people "Onondaga people") held fourteen; the [Cayuga](/wiki/Cayuga_nation "Cayuga nation") had ten seats; and the [Seneca](/wiki/Seneca_nation "Seneca nation") had eight. Representation was not based on population numbers, as the Seneca tribe greatly outnumbered the others. When a sachem chief died, his successor was chosen by the senior woman of his tribe in consultation with other female members of the clan; property and hereditary leadership were passed [matrilineally](/wiki/Matrilineality "Matrilineality"). Decisions were not made through voting but through consensus decision making, with each sachem chief holding theoretical [veto power](/wiki/Veto "Veto"). The Onondaga were the "[firekeepers](/wiki/Firekeeper "Firekeeper")", responsible for raising topics to be discussed. They occupied one side of a three-sided fire (the Mohawk and Seneca sat on one side of the fire, the Oneida and Cayuga sat on the third side.)[21]
    * Elizabeth Tooker, an [anthropologist](/wiki/Anthropologist "Anthropologist"), has said that it was unlikely theU.S.founding fathers were inspired by the confederacy, as it bears little resemblance to the system of governance adopted in the United States. For example, it is based on inherited rather than elected leadership, selected by female members of the tribes, consensus decision-making regardless of population size of the tribes, and a single group capable of bringing matters before the legislative body.[21]
    * Long-distance trading did not prevent warfare and displacement among the indigenous peoples, and their oral histories tell of numerous migrations to the historic territories where Europeans encountered them. The Iroquois invaded and attacked tribes in the Ohio River area of present-day Kentucky and claimed the hunting grounds. Historians have placed these events as occurring as early as the 13th century, or in the 17th century [Beaver Wars](/wiki/Beaver_Wars "Beaver Wars").[22]
  * Through warfare, the Iroquois drove several tribes to migrate west to what became known as their historically traditional lands west of the Mississippi River. Tribes originating in the Ohio Valley who moved west included the [Osage](/wiki/Osage_Nation "Osage Nation"), [Kaw](/wiki/Kaw_people "Kaw people"), [Ponca](/wiki/Ponca "Ponca") and [Omaha people](/wiki/Omaha_people "Omaha people"). By the mid-17th century, they had resettled in their historical lands in present-day [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas"), [Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska"), [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas") and [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"). The Osage warred with [Caddo](/wiki/Caddo "Caddo")-speaking Native Americans, displacing them in turn by the mid-18th century and dominating their new historical territories.[22]

Hawaii[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Native development in Hawaii")]

[Kamehameha I](/wiki/Kamehameha_I "Kamehameha I"), founder of the [Kingdom of
Hawaii](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hawaii "Kingdom of Hawaii").

Main article: [History of Hawaii](/wiki/History_of_Hawaii "History of Hawaii")

Native development in [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") begins with the
settlement of [Polynesians](/wiki/Polynesians "Polynesians") between [1st
century](/wiki/1st_century "1st century") to [10th century](/wiki/10th_century
"10th century"). Around 1200 AD [Tahitian](/wiki/Tahitians "Tahitians")
explorers found and began settling the area as well. This became the rise of
the Hawaiian civilization and would be separated from the rest of the world
for another 500 years until the arrival of the British. Europeans under the
British explorer [Captain James Cook](/wiki/Captain_James_Cook "Captain James
Cook") arrived in the Hawaiian Islands in 1778. Within five years of contact,
European military technology would help [Kamehameha I](/wiki/Kamehameha_I
"Kamehameha I") conquer most of the people, and eventually unify the islands
for the first time; establishing the [Kingdom of
Hawaii](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hawaii "Kingdom of Hawaii").

After a [period of exploration sponsored by major European
nations](/wiki/Exploration_of_North_America "Exploration of North America"),
the first successful English settlement was established in 1607. Europeans
brought horses, cattle, and hogs to the Americas and, in turn, took back to
Europe maize, [turkeys](/wiki/Turkey_\(bird\) "Turkey \(bird\)"), potatoes,
tobacco, beans, and [squash](/wiki/Squash_\(plant\) "Squash \(plant\)"). Many
explorers and early settlers died after being exposed to new diseases in the
Americas. The effects of new Eurasian diseases carried by the colonists,
especially smallpox and measles, were much worse for the Native Americans, as
they had no [immunity](/wiki/Immunity_\(medical\) "Immunity \(medical\)") to
them. They [suffered epidemics](/wiki/Native_American_disease_and_epidemics
"Native American disease and epidemics") and died in very large numbers,
usually before large-scale European settlement began. Their societies were
disrupted and hollowed out by the scale of deaths.[23][24]

Americas](/wiki/Dutch_colonization_of_the_Americas "Dutch colonization of the

Americas](/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas "French colonization of
the Americas")

Spanish conquests of Continental United States

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/RUIDIAZ%281893%29_1.083_JUAN_PONCE_DE_LE%C3%93N.jpg/200px-
RUIDIAZ%281893%29_1.083_JUAN_PONCE_DE_LE%C3%93N.jpg)](/wiki/File:RUIDIAZ\(1893\)_1.083_JUAN_PONCE_DE_LE%C3%93N.jpg)

The Spaniard [Juan Ponce de León](/wiki/Juan_Ponce_de_Le%C3%B3n "Juan Ponce de
León") named Florida.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Coronado-
Remington.jpg/200px-Coronado-Remington.jpg)](/wiki/File:Coronado-
Remington.jpg)

The Spanish [conquistador](/wiki/Conquistador "Conquistador")
[Coronado](/wiki/Francisco_V%C3%A1squez_de_Coronado "Francisco Vásquez de
Coronado") explored parts of the [American
Southwest](/wiki/Southwestern_United_States "Southwestern United States") from
1540 to 1542.

Spanish explorers were the first Europeans with [Christopher
Columbus](/wiki/Christopher_Columbus "Christopher Columbus")' [second
expedition](/wiki/Voyages_of_Christopher_Columbus "Voyages of Christopher
Columbus"), to reach [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico") on
November 19, 1493; others reached Florida in 1513.[25] Spanish expeditions
quickly reached the [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains
"Appalachian Mountains"), the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River
"Mississippi River"), the [Grand Canyon](/wiki/Grand_Canyon "Grand
Canyon")[26] and the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains"). In
1540, [Hernando de Soto](/wiki/Hernando_de_Soto "Hernando de Soto") undertook
an extensive exploration of the Southeast.[27]

In 1540, [Francisco Vásquez de
Coronado](/wiki/Francisco_V%C3%A1squez_de_Coronado "Francisco Vásquez de
Coronado") explored from Arizona to central Kansas.[27] Small Spanish
settlements eventually grew to become important cities, such as [San Antonio,
Texas](/wiki/San_Antonio,_Texas "San Antonio, Texas"); [Albuquerque, New
Mexico](/wiki/Albuquerque,_New_Mexico "Albuquerque, New Mexico"); [Tucson,
Arizona](/wiki/Tucson,_Arizona "Tucson, Arizona"); [Los Angeles,
California](/wiki/Los_Angeles,_California "Los Angeles, California"); and [San
Francisco, California](/wiki/San_Francisco,_California "San Francisco,
California").[28]

[New Netherland](/wiki/New_Netherland "New Netherland") was a 17th-century
Dutch colony centered on present-day [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New
York City") and the [Hudson River Valley](/wiki/Hudson_Valley "Hudson
Valley"); the Dutch traded furs with the Native Americans to the north. The
colony served as a barrier to expansion from [New England](/wiki/New_England
"New England"). Despite being Calvinists and building the [Reformed Church in
America](/wiki/Reformed_Church_in_America "Reformed Church in America"), the
Dutch were tolerant of other religions and cultures.[29]

The colony, which was taken over by Britain in 1664, left an enduring legacy
on American cultural and political life. This includes secular broad-
mindedness and mercantile pragmatism in the city as well as rural
traditionalism in the countryside (typified by the story of [Rip Van
Winkle](/wiki/Rip_Van_Winkle "Rip Van Winkle")). Notable Americans of Dutch
descent include [Martin Van Buren](/wiki/Martin_Van_Buren "Martin Van Buren"),
[Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt"), [Franklin
D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt"), [Eleanor
Roosevelt](/wiki/Eleanor_Roosevelt "Eleanor Roosevelt") and the
[Frelinghuysens](/wiki/Frelinghuysen_\(disambiguation\) "Frelinghuysen
\(disambiguation\)").[29]

[New France](/wiki/New_France "New France") was the area [colonized by
France](/wiki/French_colonization_of_the_Americas "French colonization of the
Americas") from 1534 to 1763. There were few permanent settlers outside
[Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") and [Acadia](/wiki/Acadia "Acadia"), but the
French had far-reaching trading relationships with Native Americans throughout
the Great Lakes and Midwest. French villages along the
[Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River") and [Illinois
rivers](/wiki/Illinois_River "Illinois River") were based in farming
communities that served as a granary for Gulf Coast settlements. The French
established plantations in Louisiana along with settling [New
Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans"), [Mobile](/wiki/Mobile,_Alabama
"Mobile, Alabama") and [Biloxi](/wiki/Biloxi "Biloxi").

The [Wabanaki Confederacy](/wiki/Wabanaki_Confederacy "Wabanaki Confederacy")
were military allies of New France through the four French and Indian Wars
while the British colonies were allied with the [Iroquois
Confederacy](/wiki/Iroquois_Confederacy "Iroquois Confederacy"). During the
[French and Indian War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian War") –
the North American theater of the [Seven Years' War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War
"Seven Years' War") – New England fought successfully against French Acadia.
The British removed [Acadians](/wiki/Acadians "Acadians") from
[Acadia](/wiki/Acadia "Acadia") ([Nova Scotia](/wiki/Nova_Scotia "Nova
Scotia")) and replaced them with [New England
Planters](/wiki/New_England_Planters "New England Planters").[30] Eventually,
some Acadians resettled in Louisiana, where they developed a distinctive rural
[Cajun](/wiki/Cajun "Cajun") culture that still exists. They became American
citizens in 1803 with the [Louisiana Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase
"Louisiana Purchase").[31] Other French villages along the
[Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River") and [Illinois
rivers](/wiki/Illinois_River "Illinois River") were absorbed when the
Americans started arriving after 1770, or settlers moved west to escape
them.[32] French influence and language in [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans
"New Orleans"), [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") and the Gulf Coast
was more enduring; New Orleans was notable for its large population of [free
people of color](/wiki/Free_people_of_color "Free people of color") before the
Civil War.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Mayflower_in_Plymouth_Harbor%2C_by_William_Halsall.jpg/300px-
Mayflower_in_Plymouth_Harbor%2C_by_William_Halsall.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mayflower_in_Plymouth_Harbor,_by_William_Halsall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mayflower_in_Plymouth_Harbor,_by_William_Halsall.jpg "Enlarge")

The _[Mayflower](/wiki/Mayflower "Mayflower")_ , which transported
[Pilgrims](/wiki/Pilgrim_\(Plymouth_Colony\) "Pilgrim \(Plymouth Colony\)") to
the New World. During the first winter at Plymouth, about half of the Pilgrims
died.[33]

The strip of land along the eastern seacoast was settled primarily by English
colonists in the 17th century along with much smaller numbers of
[Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_people "Dutch people") and
[Swedes](/wiki/Swedish_ethnic_group "Swedish ethnic group"). Colonial America
was defined by a severe labor shortage that employed forms of [unfree
labor](/wiki/Unfree_labor "Unfree labor") such as
[slavery](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_colonial_United_States "Slavery in the colonial
United States") and [indentured servitude](/wiki/Indentured_servitude
"Indentured servitude") and by a British policy of benign neglect ([salutary
neglect](/wiki/Salutary_neglect "Salutary neglect")). Over half of all
European immigrants to Colonial America arrived as indentured servants.[34]
Salutary neglect permitted the development of an American spirit distinct from
that of its European founders.[35]

Squantoteaching.png)](/wiki/File:Squantoteaching.png)

[Squanto](/wiki/Squanto "Squanto") known for having been an early liaison
between the native populations in Southern New England and the Mayflower
settlers, who made their settlement at the site of Squanto's former summer
village.

The first successful English colony, [Jamestown](/wiki/Jamestown,_Virginia
"Jamestown, Virginia"), was established in 1607 on the [James
River](/wiki/James_River_\(Virginia\) "James River \(Virginia\)") in
[Virginia](/wiki/Virginia "Virginia"). Jamestown languished for decades until
a new wave of settlers arrived in the late 17th century and established
commercial agriculture based on [tobacco](/wiki/Tobacco "Tobacco"). Between
the late 1610s and the Revolution, the British shipped an estimated 50,000 to
120,000 convicts to their American colonies.[36] A severe instance of conflict
was the 1622 [Powhatan](/wiki/Powhatan "Powhatan") uprising in Virginia in
which Native Americans killed hundreds of English settlers. The largest
conflicts between Native Americans and English settlers in the 17th century
were [King Philip's War](/wiki/King_Philip%27s_War "King Philip's War") in
[New England](/wiki/New_England "New England")[37] and the [Yamasee
War](/wiki/Yamasee_War "Yamasee War") in South Carolina.[38]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Thanksgiving-
Brownscombe.jpg/250px-Thanksgiving-Brownscombe.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thanksgiving-
Brownscombe.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Thanksgiving-Brownscombe.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jennie Augusta Brownscombe](/wiki/Jennie_Augusta_Brownscombe "Jennie Augusta
Brownscombe"), The First Thanksgiving at Plymouth, 1914, Pilgrim Hall Museum,
Plymouth, Massachusetts

[New England](/wiki/New_England "New England") was initially settled primarily
by [Puritans](/wiki/Puritans "Puritans"). The [Pilgrims](/wiki/Pilgrim
"Pilgrim") established a settlement in 1620 at [Plymouth
Colony](/wiki/Plymouth_Colony "Plymouth Colony"), which was followed by the
establishment of the [Massachusetts Bay Colony](/wiki/Massachusetts_Bay_Colony
"Massachusetts Bay Colony") in 1630. The Middle Colonies, consisting of the
present-day states of [New York](/wiki/History_of_New_York_\(state\) "History
of New York \(state\)"), [New Jersey](/wiki/History_of_New_Jersey "History of
New Jersey"), [Pennsylvania](/wiki/History_of_Pennsylvania "History of
Pennsylvania"), and [Delaware](/wiki/History_of_Delaware "History of
Delaware"), were characterized by a large degree of diversity. The first
attempted English settlement south of Virginia was the [Province of
Carolina](/wiki/Province_of_Carolina "Province of Carolina"), with [Georgia
Colony](/wiki/Province_of_Georgia "Province of Georgia") – the last of the
[Thirteen Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") – established
in 1733.[39]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/1622_massacre_jamestown_de_Bry.jpg/250px-1622_massacre_jamestown_de_Bry.jpg)](/wiki/File:1622_massacre_jamestown_de_Bry.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1622_massacre_jamestown_de_Bry.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Indian massacre of Jamestown settlers](/wiki/Indian_massacre_of_1622
"Indian massacre of 1622") in 1622. Soon the colonists in the South feared all
natives as enemies.

The colonies were characterized by people primarily of the Judeo-Christian
faiths, with many Congregationalists in New England, German and Dutch Reformed
in the Middle Colonies, Catholics in Maryland, and [Scots-Irish](/wiki/Scotch-
Irish_American "Scotch-Irish American") Presbyterians on the frontier.
[Sephardic Jews](/wiki/Sephardic_Jews "Sephardic Jews") were among early
settlers in cities of New England and the South. Many immigrants arrived as
religious refugees: [French Huguenots](/wiki/French_Huguenot "French
Huguenot") settled in New York, Virginia and the Carolinas. Many royal
officials and merchants were Anglicans.[40]

Religiosity expanded greatly after the [First Great
Awakening](/wiki/First_Great_Awakening "First Great Awakening"), a religious
revival in the 1740s led by preachers such as [Jonathan
Edwards](/wiki/Jonathan_Edwards_\(theologian\) "Jonathan Edwards
\(theologian\)") and [George Whitefield](/wiki/George_Whitefield "George
Whitefield"). American Evangelicals affected by the Awakening added a new
emphasis on divine outpourings of the Holy Spirit and conversions that
implanted within new believers an intense love for God. Revivals encapsulated
those hallmarks and carried the newly created evangelicalism into the early
republic, setting the stage for the [Second Great
Awakening](/wiki/Second_Great_Awakening "Second Great Awakening") beginning in
the late 1790s.[41] In the early stages, evangelicals in the South such as
Methodists and Baptists preached for religious freedom and abolition of
slavery; they converted many slaves and recognized some as preachers.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Baptism_of_Pocahontas.jpg/220px-
Baptism_of_Pocahontas.jpg)](/wiki/File:Baptism_of_Pocahontas.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Baptism_of_Pocahontas.jpg "Enlarge")

[John Gadsby Chapman](/wiki/John_Gadsby_Chapman "John Gadsby Chapman"), _The
Baptism of[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas "Pocahontas")_ (1840). A copy is on
display in the Rotunda of the U.S.
[Capitol](/w/index.php?title=U.S_Capitol&action=edit&redlink=1 "U.S Capitol
\(page does not exist\)").

Each of the 13 American colonies had a slightly different governmental
structure. Typically, a colony was ruled by a governor appointed from London
who controlled the executive administration and relied upon a locally elected
legislature to vote taxes and make laws. By the 18th century, the American
colonies were growing very rapidly as a result of low death rates along with
ample supplies of land and food. The colonies were richer than most parts of
Britain, and attracted a steady flow of immigrants, especially teenagers who
arrived as indentured servants.[42]

The tobacco and rice plantations imported African
[slaves](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States")
for labor from the British colonies in the West Indies, and by the 1770s
African slaves comprised a fifth of the American population. The question of
independence from Britain did not arise as long as the colonies needed British
military support against the French and Spanish powers. Those threats were
gone by 1765. London regarded the American colonies as existing for the
benefit of the mother country. This policy is known as
[mercantilism](/wiki/Mercantilism "Mercantilism").[42]

## 18th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: 18th century")]

An upper-class, with wealth based on large plantations operated by slave
labor, and holding significant political power and even control over the
churches, emerged in South Carolina and Virginia. A unique class system
operated in upstate New York, where Dutch tenant farmers rented land from very
wealthy Dutch proprietors, such as the Rensselaer family. The other colonies
were more equalitarian, with Pennsylvania being representative. By the
mid-18th century Pennsylvania was basically a middle-class colony with limited
deference to its small upper-class. A writer in the _Pennsylvania Journal_ in
1756 summed it up:

> The People of this Province are generally of the middling Sort, and at
> present pretty much upon a Level. They are chiefly industrious Farmers,
> Artificers or Men in Trade; they enjoy in are fond of Freedom, and the
> _meanest among them_ thinks he has a right to Civility from the
> greatest.[43]

### Political integration and
autonomy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Political integration and autonomy")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Benjamin_Franklin_-
_Join_or_Die.jpg/220px-Benjamin_Franklin_-
_Join_or_Die.jpg)](/wiki/File:Benjamin_Franklin_-_Join_or_Die.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Benjamin_Franklin_-_Join_or_Die.jpg "Enlarge")

[Join, or Die](/wiki/Join,_or_Die "Join, or Die"): This 1756 political cartoon
by [Benjamin Franklin](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin "Benjamin Franklin") urged the
colonies to join together during the French and Indian War.

The [French and Indian War](/wiki/French_and_Indian_War "French and Indian
War") (1754–63) was a watershed event in the political development of the
colonies. It was also part of the larger [Seven Years'
War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years' War"). The influence of the main
rivals of the British Crown in the colonies and Canada, the French and North
American Indians, was significantly reduced with the territory of the
[Thirteen Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") expanding
into [New France](/wiki/New_France "New France") both in Canada and the
[Louisiana Territory](/wiki/Louisiana_Territory "Louisiana Territory").
Moreover, the war effort resulted in greater political integration of the
colonies, as reflected in the [Albany Congress](/wiki/Albany_Congress "Albany
Congress") and symbolized by [Benjamin Franklin](/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin
"Benjamin Franklin")'s call for the colonies to "Join or Die". Franklin was a
man of many inventions – one of which was the concept of a United States of
America, which emerged after 1765 and was realized in July 1776.[44]

Following Britain's acquisition of French territory in North America, [King
George III](/wiki/King_George_III "King George III") issued the [Royal
Proclamation of 1763](/wiki/Royal_Proclamation_of_1763 "Royal Proclamation of
1763") with the goal of organizing the new North American empire and
protecting the native Indians from colonial expansion into western lands
beyond the Appalachian Mountains. In ensuing years, strains developed in the
relations between the colonists and the Crown. The [British
Parliament](/wiki/British_Parliament "British Parliament") passed the [Stamp
Act of 1765](/wiki/Stamp_Act_of_1765 "Stamp Act of 1765"), imposing a tax on
the colonies without going through the colonial legislatures. The issue was
drawn: did Parliament have this right to tax Americans who were not
represented in it? Crying "[No taxation without
representation](/wiki/No_taxation_without_representation "No taxation without
representation")", the colonists refused to pay the taxes as tensions
escalated in the late 1760s and early 1770s.[45]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Population_Density_in_the_American_Colonies_1775.gif/300px-
Population_Density_in_the_American_Colonies_1775.gif)](/wiki/File:Population_Density_in_the_American_Colonies_1775.gif)

The population density in the [American Colonies](/wiki/American_Colonies

The [Boston Tea Party](/wiki/Boston_Tea_Party "Boston Tea Party") in 1773 was
a direct action by activists in the town of Boston to protest against the new
tax on tea. Parliament quickly responded the next year with the [Coercive
Acts](/wiki/Coercive_Acts "Coercive Acts"), stripping Massachusetts of its
historic right of self-government and putting it under army rule, which
sparked outrage and resistance in all thirteen colonies. Patriot leaders from
all 13 colonies convened the [First Continental
Congress](/wiki/First_Continental_Congress "First Continental Congress") to
coordinate their resistance to the Coercive Acts. The Congress called for a
[boycott of British trade](/wiki/Continental_Association "Continental
Association"), published a [list of rights and
grievances](/wiki/Declaration_and_Resolves "Declaration and Resolves"), and
[petitioned the king](/wiki/Petition_to_the_King_\(1774\) "Petition to the
King \(1774\)") for redress of those grievances.[46] The appeal to the Crown
had no effect, and so the [Second Continental
Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second Continental Congress") was
convened in 1775 to organize the defense of the colonies against the British
Army.

Ordinary folk became insurgents against the British even though they were
unfamiliar with the ideological rationales being offered. They held very
strongly a sense of "rights" that they felt the British were deliberately
violating – rights that stressed local autonomy, fair dealing, and government
by consent. They were highly sensitive to the issue of tyranny, which they saw
manifested in the arrival in Boston of the British Army to punish the
Bostonians. This heightened their sense of violated rights, leading to rage
and demands for revenge. They had faith that God was on their side.[47]

The [American Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American
Revolutionary War") began at Concord and Lexington in April 1775 when the
British tried to seize ammunition supplies and arrest the Patriot leaders.

In terms of political values, the Americans were largely united on a concept
called [Republicanism](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism
in the United States"), that rejected aristocracy and emphasized civic duty
and a fear of corruption. For the Founding Fathers, according to one team of
historians, "republicanism represented more than a particular form of
government. It was a way of life, a core ideology, an uncompromising
commitment to liberty, and a total rejection of aristocracy."[48]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-
NYC%2C_1851.jpg/220px-
Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-

[](/wiki/File:Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze,_MMA-
NYC,_1851.jpg "Enlarge")

[Washington's surprise crossing of the Delaware
River](/wiki/Washington%27s_crossing_of_the_Delaware_River "Washington's
crossing of the Delaware River") in Dec. 1776 was a major comeback after the
loss of New York City; his army defeated the British in two battles and
recaptured New Jersey.

The [Thirteen Colonies](/wiki/Thirteen_Colonies "Thirteen Colonies") began a
rebellion against British rule in 1775 and proclaimed their independence in
1776 as the United States of America. In the [American Revolutionary
War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War") (1775–83)
the Americans captured the British invasion army at [Saratoga in
1777](/wiki/Battles_of_Saratoga "Battles of Saratoga"), secured the Northeast
and encouraged the French to make a military alliance with the United States.
France brought in Spain and the Netherlands, thus balancing the military and
naval forces on each side as Britain had no allies.[49]

General [George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington")
(1732–99) proved an excellent organizer and administrator, who worked
successfully with Congress and the state governors, selecting and mentoring
his senior officers, supporting and training his troops, and maintaining an
idealistic Republican Army. His biggest challenge was logistics, since neither
Congress nor the states had the funding to provide adequately for the
equipment, munitions, clothing, paychecks, or even the food supply of the
soldiers.

As a battlefield tactician, Washington was often outmaneuvered by his British
counterparts. As a strategist, however, he had a better idea of how to win the
war than they did. The British sent four invasion armies. Washington's
strategy forced the first army out of Boston in 1776, and was responsible for
the surrender of the second and third armies at Saratoga (1777) and Yorktown
(1781). He limited the British control to New York City and a few places while
keeping Patriot control of the great majority of the population.[50]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg/220px-
Declaration_of_Independence_%281819%29%2C_by_John_Trumbull.jpg)](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Independence_\(1819\),_by_John_Trumbull.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Declaration_of_Independence_\(1819\),_by_John_Trumbull.jpg
"Enlarge")

[Trumbull's Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/Trumbull%27s_Declaration_of_Independence "Trumbull's
Declaration of Independence")

The Loyalists, whom the British counted upon too heavily, comprised about 20%
of the population but never were well organized. As the war ended, Washington
watched proudly as the final British army quietly sailed out of New York City
in November 1783, taking the Loyalist leadership with them. Washington
astonished the world when, instead of seizing power for himself, he retired
quietly to his farm in Virginia.[50] Political scientist [Seymour Martin
Lipset](/wiki/Seymour_Martin_Lipset "Seymour Martin Lipset") observes, "The
United States was the first major colony successfully to revolt against
colonial rule. In this sense, it was the first 'new nation'."[51]

On July 4, 1776, the [Second Continental
Congress](/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress "Second Continental Congress"),
meeting in [Philadelphia](/wiki/Philadelphia "Philadelphia"), declared the
independence of "the United States of America" in the [Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence "United States
Declaration of Independence"). July 4 is celebrated as the nation's birthday.
Historian George Billias says:

    Independence amounted to a new status of interdependence: the United States was now a sovereign nation entitled to the privileges and responsibilities that came with that status. America thus became a member of the international community, which meant becoming a maker of treaties and alliances, a military ally in diplomacy, and a partner in foreign trade on a more equal basis.[52]

The new nation was founded on [Enlightenment](/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment "Age
of Enlightenment") ideals of liberalism in what [Thomas
Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") called the unalienable
rights to "life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness", and dedicated strongly
to [republican](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism in the
United States") principles. Republicanism emphasized the people are sovereign
(not hereditary kings), demanded civic duty, feared corruption, and rejected
any aristocracy.[53]

Every nation constructs and honors the memory of its founding; following
generations use it to establish its identity and define patriotism.[54][55]
The Revolution became the main source of the non-denominational "[American
civil religion](/wiki/American_civil_religion "American civil religion")" that
has shaped patriotism, and the memory and meaning of the nation's birth ever
since. Key events and people were viewed as icons of fundamental virtues. Thus
the Revolution produced a Moses-like leader (George Washington),[56] prophets
(Thomas Jefferson, Tom Paine), disciples (Alexander Hamilton, James Madison)
and martyrs (Boston Massacre, Nathan Hale), as well as devils (Benedict
Arnold). There are sacred places (Valley Forge, Bunker Hill), rituals (Boston
Tea Party), emblems (the new flag), sacred days (Independence Day), and sacred
scriptures whose every sentence is carefully studied (The Declaration of
Independence, the Constitution and the Bill of Rights).[57]
