### Confederation and
Constitution[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Confederation and Constitution")]

Further information: [Articles of
Confederation](/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation "Articles of Confederation")
and [History of the United States
Constitution](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_Constitution "History of the
United States Constitution")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/GROWTH1850.JPG/400px-
GROWTH1850.JPG)](/wiki/File:GROWTH1850.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:GROWTH1850.JPG "Enlarge")

Economic growth in America per capita income. Index with 1700 set as 100.

In the 1780s the national government was able to settle the issue of the
western territories, which were ceded by the states to Congress and became
territories. With the migration of settlers to the Northwest, soon they became
states. Nationalists worried that the new nation was too fragile to withstand
an international war, or even internal revolts such as the [Shays'
Rebellion](/wiki/Shays%27_Rebellion "Shays' Rebellion") of 1786 in
Massachusetts.[58]

Nationalists – most of them war veterans – organized in every state and
convinced Congress to call the [Philadelphia
Convention](/wiki/Philadelphia_Convention "Philadelphia Convention") in 1787.
The delegates from every state wrote a new
[Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
that created a much more powerful and efficient central government, one with a
strong president, and powers of taxation. The new government reflected the
prevailing republican ideals of guarantees of [individual
liberty](/wiki/Natural_rights "Natural rights") and of constraining the power
of government through a system of [separation of
powers](/wiki/Separation_of_powers "Separation of powers").[58]

The Congress was given authority to ban the international [slave
trade](/wiki/Slave_trade "Slave trade") after 20 years (which it did in 1807).
A compromise gave the South Congressional apportionment out of proportion to
its free population by allowing it to include three-fifths of the number of
slaves in each state's total population. This provision increased the
political power of southern representatives in Congress, especially as slavery
was extended into the Deep South through removal of Native Americans and
transportation of slaves by an extensive domestic trade.

To assuage the Anti-Federalists who feared a too-powerful national government,
the nation adopted the [United States Bill of
Rights](/wiki/United_States_Bill_of_Rights "United States Bill of Rights") in
1791. Comprising the first ten amendments of the Constitution, it guaranteed
individual liberties such as freedom of speech and religious practice, jury
trials, and stated that citizens and states had reserved rights (which were
not specified).[59]

### The new Chief
Executive[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: The new Chief Executive")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Stuart-george-
washington-constable-1797.jpg/220px-Stuart-george-washington-
constable-1797.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg "Enlarge")

[George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington") legacy
remains among the two or three greatest in American history, as Commander-in-
Chief of the Continental Army, hero of the Revolution, and the first President
of the United States.

[George Washington](/wiki/George_Washington "George Washington") – a renowned
hero of the [American Revolutionary War](/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War
"American Revolutionary War"), commander-in-chief of the [Continental
Army](/wiki/Continental_Army "Continental Army"), and president of the
[Constitutional Convention](/wiki/Philadelphia_Convention "Philadelphia
Convention") – became the first President of the United States under the new
[Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution")
in 1789. The national capital moved from New York to Philadelphia and finally
settled in Washington DC in 1800.

The major accomplishments of the [Washington
Administration](/wiki/Presidency_of_George_Washington "Presidency of George
Washington") were creating a strong national government that was recognized
without question by all Americans.[60] His government, following the vigorous
leadership of [Treasury
Secretary](/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Treasury "United States
Secretary of the Treasury") [Alexander Hamilton](/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton
"Alexander Hamilton"), assumed the debts of the states (the debt holders
received federal bonds), created the [Bank of the United
States](/wiki/First_Bank_of_the_United_States "First Bank of the United
States") to stabilize the financial system, and set up a uniform system of
tariffs (taxes on imports) and other taxes to pay off the debt and provide a
financial infrastructure. To support his programs Hamilton created a new
political party – the first in the world based on voters – the [Federalist
Party](/wiki/Federalist_Party_\(United_States\) "Federalist Party \(United
States\)").

[Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") and [James
Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison") formed an opposition Republican
Party (usually called the [Democratic-Republican Party](/wiki/Democratic-
Republican_Party "Democratic-Republican Party") by political scientists).
Hamilton and Washington presented the country in 1794 with the [Jay
Treaty](/wiki/Jay_Treaty "Jay Treaty") that reestablished good relations with
Britain. The Jeffersonians vehemently protested, and the voters aligned behind
one party or the other, thus setting up the [First Party
System](/wiki/First_Party_System "First Party System").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Election_Day_1815_by_John_Lewis_Krimmel.jpg/300px-
Election_Day_1815_by_John_Lewis_Krimmel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Election_Day_1815_by_John_Lewis_Krimmel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Election_Day_1815_by_John_Lewis_Krimmel.jpg "Enlarge")

Depiction of election-day activities in Philadelphia by [John Lewis
Krimmel](/wiki/John_Lewis_Krimmel "John Lewis Krimmel"), 1815

Federalists promoted business, financial and commercial interests and wanted
more trade with Britain. Republicans accused the Federalists of plans to
establish a monarchy, turn the rich into a ruling class, and making the United
States a pawn of the British.[61] The treaty passed, but politics became
intensely heated.[62]

The [Whiskey Rebellion](/wiki/Whiskey_Rebellion "Whiskey Rebellion") in 1794,
when western settlers protested against a federal tax on liquor, was the first
serious test of the federal government. Washington called out the state
militia and personally led an army, as the insurgents melted away and the
power of the national government was firmly established.[63]

Washington refused to serve more than two terms – setting a precedent – and in
his famous [farewell address](/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Farewell_Address
"George Washington's Farewell Address"), he extolled the benefits of federal
government and importance of ethics and morality while warning against foreign
alliances and the formation of political parties.[64]

[John Adams](/wiki/John_Adams "John Adams"), a Federalist, defeated Jefferson
in the 1796 election. War loomed with France and the Federalists used the
opportunity to try to silence the Republicans with the [Alien and Sedition
Acts](/wiki/Alien_and_Sedition_Acts "Alien and Sedition Acts"), build up a
large army with Hamilton at the head, and prepare for a French invasion.
However, the Federalists became divided after Adams sent a successful peace
mission to France that ended the [Quasi-War](/wiki/Quasi-War "Quasi-War") of
1798.[61][65]

###
Slavery[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Slavery")]

Main article: [Slavery in the United
States](/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States "Slavery in the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/Crowe-
Slaves_Waiting_for_Sale_-_Richmond%2C_Virginia.jpg/250px-Crowe-
Slaves_Waiting_for_Sale_-_Richmond%2C_Virginia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Crowe-
Slaves_Waiting_for_Sale_-_Richmond,_Virginia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Crowe-Slaves_Waiting_for_Sale_-_Richmond,_Virginia.jpg
"Enlarge")

_Slaves Waiting for Sale: Richmond, Virginia_. Painted upon the sketch of 1853

During the first two decades after the Revolutionary War, there were dramatic
changes in the status of slavery among the states and an increase in the
number of [freed blacks](/wiki/Free_negro "Free negro"). Inspired by
revolutionary ideals of the equality of men and influenced by their lesser
economic reliance on slavery, northern states abolished slavery.

States of the [Upper South](/wiki/Upper_South "Upper South") made
[manumission](/wiki/Manumission "Manumission") easier, resulting in an
increase in the proportion of [free blacks](/wiki/Free_negro "Free negro") in
the Upper South (as a percentage of the total non-white population) from less
than one percent in 1792 to more than 10 percent by 1810. By that date, a
total of 13.5 percent of all blacks in the United States were free.[66] After
that date, with the demand for slaves on the rise because of the Deep South's
expanding cotton cultivation, the number of manumissions declined sharply; and
an internal U.S. slave trade became an important source of wealth for many
planters and traders.

In 1809, president [James Madison](/wiki/James_Madison "James Madison")
severed the US's involvement with the [Atlantic slave
trade](/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade "Atlantic slave trade").

## 19th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: 19th century")]

### Jeffersonian Republican
Era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Jeffersonian Republican Era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Thomas-
Jefferson.jpg/200px-Thomas-Jefferson.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thomas-Jefferson.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Thomas-Jefferson.jpg "Enlarge")

Jefferson saw himself as a man of the frontier and a scientist; he was keenly
interested in expanding and exploring the West.

Jefferson's major achievement as president was the [Louisiana
Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase "Louisiana Purchase") in 1803, which
provided U.S. settlers with vast potential for expansion west of the
Mississippi River.[67]

Jefferson, a scientist himself, supported expeditions to explore and map the
new domain, most notably the [Lewis and Clark
Expedition](/wiki/Lewis_and_Clark_Expedition "Lewis and Clark
Expedition").[68] Jefferson believed deeply in
[republicanism](/wiki/Republicanism_in_the_United_States "Republicanism in the
United States") and argued it should be based on the independent
[yeoman](/wiki/Yeoman "Yeoman") farmer and planter; he distrusted cities,
factories and banks. He also distrusted the federal government and judges, and
tried to weaken the judiciary. However he met his match in [John
Marshall](/wiki/John_Marshall "John Marshall"), a Federalist from Virginia.
Although the Constitution specified a [Supreme
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States"), its functions were vague until Marshall, the Chief Justice
(1801–35), defined them, especially the power to overturn acts of Congress or
states that violated the Constitution, first enunciated in 1803 in _[Marbury
v. Madison](/wiki/Marbury_v._Madison "Marbury v. Madison")_.[69]

### War of
1812[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: War of 1812")]

Main article: [War of 1812](/wiki/War_of_1812 "War of 1812")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/UnitedStatesExpansion.png/350px-
UnitedStatesExpansion.png)](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesExpansion.png)

[](/wiki/File:UnitedStatesExpansion.png "Enlarge")

Territorial expansion; [Louisiana Purchase](/wiki/Louisiana_Purchase
"Louisiana Purchase") in white.

[Thomas Jefferson](/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson "Thomas Jefferson") defeated Adams
for the presidency in the [1800
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1800 "United States
presidential election, 1800"). Americans were increasingly angry at the
British violation of American ships' neutral rights in order to hurt France,
the [impressment](/wiki/Impressment "Impressment") (seizure) of 10,000
American sailors needed by the Royal Navy to fight Napoleon, and British
support for hostile Indians attacking American settlers in the Midwest. They
may also have desired to annex all or part of British North
America.[70][71][72][73][74] Despite strong opposition from the Northeast,
especially from Federalists who did not want to disrupt trade with Britain,
Congress declared war on June 18, 1812.[75]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Battle_erie.jpg/250px-
Battle_erie.jpg)](/wiki/File:Battle_erie.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Battle_erie.jpg "Enlarge")

Oliver Hazard Perry's message to William Henry Harrison after the Battle of
Lake Erie began with what would become one of the most famous sentences in
American military history: "We have met the enemy and they are ours".[citation
needed] This 1865 painting by William H. Powell shows Perry transferring to a
different ship during the battle.

The war was frustrating for both sides. Both sides tried to invade the other
and were repulsed. The American high command remained incompetent until the
last year. The American militia proved ineffective because the soldiers were
reluctant to leave home and efforts to invade Canada repeatedly failed. The
British blockade ruined American commerce, bankrupted the Treasury, and
further angered New Englanders, who smuggled supplies to Britain. The
Americans under General [William Henry Harrison](/wiki/William_Henry_Harrison
"William Henry Harrison") finally gained naval control of Lake Erie and
defeated the Indians under [Tecumseh](/wiki/Tecumseh "Tecumseh") in
Canada,[76] while Andrew Jackson ended the Indian threat in the Southeast. The
Indian threat to expansion into the Midwest was permanently ended. The British
invaded and occupied much of Maine.

The British raided and burned Washington, but were repelled at Baltimore in
1814 – where the ["Star Spangled Banner"](/wiki/The_Star-Spangled_Banner "The
Star-Spangled Banner") was written to celebrate the American success. In
upstate New York a major British invasion of New York State was turned back.
Finally in early 1815 [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson")
decisively defeated a major British invasion at the [Battle of New
Orleans](/wiki/Battle_of_New_Orleans "Battle of New Orleans"), making him the
most famous war hero.[77]

With Napoleon (apparently) gone, the causes of the war had evaporated and both
sides agreed to a peace that left the prewar boundaries intact. Americans
claimed victory on February 18, 1815 as news came almost simultaneously of
Jackson's victory of New Orleans and the [peace treaty](/wiki/Treaty_of_Ghent
"Treaty of Ghent") that left the prewar boundaries in place. Americans swelled
with pride at success in the "second war of independence"; the naysayers of
the antiwar Federalist Party were put to shame and the party never recovered.
The Indians were the big losers; they never gained the independent nationhood
Britain had promised and no longer posed a serious threat as settlers poured
into the Midwest.[77]

### Era of Good
Feelings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Era of Good Feelings")]

Main article: [Era of Good Feelings](/wiki/Era_of_Good_Feelings "Era of Good
Feelings")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Independence_Day_Celebration_in_Centre_Square.jpg/250px-
Independence_Day_Celebration_in_Centre_Square.jpg)](/wiki/File:Independence_Day_Celebration_in_Centre_Square.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Independence_Day_Celebration_in_Centre_Square.jpg "Enlarge")

[Era of Good Feelings](/wiki/Era_of_Good_Feelings "Era of Good Feelings")

As strong opponents of the war, the Federalists held the [Hartford
Convention](/wiki/Hartford_Convention "Hartford Convention") in 1814 that
hinted at disunion. National euphoria after the victory at New Orleans ruined
the prestige of the Federalists and they no longer played a significant role
as a political party.[78] President Madison and most Republicans realized they
were foolish to let the Bank of the United States close down, for its absence
greatly hindered the financing of the war. So, with the assistance of foreign
bankers, they chartered the [Second Bank of the United
States](/wiki/Second_Bank_of_the_United_States "Second Bank of the United
States") in 1816.[79][80]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Pioneers_Crossing_the_Plains_of_Nebraska_by_C.C.A._Christensen.png/250px-
Pioneers_Crossing_the_Plains_of_Nebraska_by_C.C.A._Christensen.png)](/wiki/File:Pioneers_Crossing_the_Plains_of_Nebraska_by_C.C.A._Christensen.png)

[](/wiki/File:Pioneers_Crossing_the_Plains_of_Nebraska_by_C.C.A._Christensen.png
"Enlarge")

Settlers crossing the [Plains of Nebraska](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains").

The Republicans also imposed tariffs designed to protect the infant industries
that had been created when Britain was blockading the U.S. With the collapse
of the Federalists as a party, the adoption of many Federalist principles by
the Republicans, and the systematic policy of President [James
Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe "James Monroe") in his two terms (1817–25) to
downplay partisanship, the nation entered an [Era of Good
Feelings](/wiki/Era_of_Good_Feelings "Era of Good Feelings"), with far less
partisanship than before (or after), and closed out the [First Party
System](/wiki/First_Party_System "First Party System").[79][80]

The [Monroe Doctrine](/wiki/Monroe_Doctrine "Monroe Doctrine"), expressed in
1823, proclaimed the United States' opinion that European powers should no
longer colonize or interfere in the Americas. This was a defining moment in
the [foreign policy of the United
States](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States "Foreign policy of the
United States"). The Monroe Doctrine was adopted in response to American and
British fears over Russian and French expansion into the [Western
Hemisphere](/wiki/Western_Hemisphere "Western Hemisphere").[81]

In 1832, President [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson"),
7th President of the United States, ran for a second term under the slogan
"Jackson and no bank" and did not renew the charter of the Second Bank of the
United States of America, ending the Bank in 1836.[82] Jackson was convinced
that central banking was used by the elite to take advantage of the average
American, and instead implemented state banks, popularly known as "pet
banks."[82]

### Indian
removal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Indian removal")]

Main article: [Indian removal](/wiki/Indian_removal "Indian removal")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Trails_of_Tears_en.png/350px-
Trails_of_Tears_en.png)](/wiki/File:Trails_of_Tears_en.png)

[](/wiki/File:Trails_of_Tears_en.png "Enlarge")

The Indian Removal Act resulted in the transplantation of several [Native
American tribes](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native Americans
in the United States") and the [Trail of Tears](/wiki/Trail_of_Tears "Trail of
Tears").

In 1830, Congress passed the [Indian Removal Act](/wiki/Indian_Removal_Act
"Indian Removal Act"), which authorized the president to negotiate treaties
that exchanged Native American tribal lands in the eastern states for lands
west of the Mississippi River.[83] Its goal was primarily to remove Native
Americans, including the [Five Civilized Tribes](/wiki/Five_Civilized_Tribes
"Five Civilized Tribes"), from the American Southeast; they occupied land that
settlers wanted. [Jacksonian Democrats](/wiki/Jacksonian_democracy "Jacksonian
democracy") demanded the forcible removal of native populations who refused to
acknowledge state laws to reservations in the West; Whigs and religious
leaders opposed the move as inhumane. Thousands of deaths resulted from the
relocations, as seen in the [Cherokee](/wiki/Cherokee "Cherokee") [Trail of
Tears](/wiki/Trail_of_Tears "Trail of Tears").[84] Many of the [Seminole
Indians](/wiki/Seminole_Indians "Seminole Indians") in Florida refused to move
west; they fought the Army for years in the [Seminole
Wars](/wiki/Seminole_Wars "Seminole Wars").

### Second Party
System[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Second Party System")]

Main articles: [Second Party System](/wiki/Second_Party_System "Second Party
System") and [Presidency of Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Presidency_of_Andrew_Jackson
"Presidency of Andrew Jackson")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Clay.png/200px-
Clay.png)](/wiki/File:Clay.png)

[](/wiki/File:Clay.png "Enlarge")

[Henry Clay](/wiki/Henry_Clay "Henry Clay")

After the [First Party System](/wiki/First_Party_System "First Party System")
of Federalists and Republicans withered away in the 1820s, the stage was set
for the emergence of a new party system based on well organized local parties
that appealed for the votes of (almost) all adult white men. The former
Jeffersonian (Democratic-Republican) party split into factions. They split
over the choice of a successor to President [James Monroe](/wiki/James_Monroe
"James Monroe"), and the party faction that supported many of the old
Jeffersonian principles, led by [Andrew Jackson](/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew
Jackson") and [Martin Van Buren](/wiki/Martin_Van_Buren "Martin Van Buren"),
became the Democratic Party. As Norton explains the transformation in 1828:

> Jacksonians believed the people's will had finally prevailed. Through a
> lavishly financed coalition of state parties, political leaders, and
> newspaper editors, a popular movement had elected the president. The
> Democrats became the nation's first well-organized national party...and
> tight party organization became the hallmark of nineteenth-century American
> politics.[85]

Opposing factions led by [Henry Clay](/wiki/Henry_Clay "Henry Clay") helped
form the [Whig Party](/wiki/Whig_Party_\(United_States\) "Whig Party \(United
States\)"). The Democratic Party had a small but decisive advantage over the
Whigs until the 1850s, when the Whigs fell apart over the issue of slavery.

Behind the platforms issued by state and national parties stood a widely
shared political outlook that characterized the Democrats:

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Clay44b.jpg/200px-
Clay44b.jpg)](/wiki/File:Clay44b.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Clay44b.jpg "Enlarge")

[Horace Greeley](/wiki/Horace_Greeley "Horace Greeley")'s _New York Tribune_
—the leading Whig paper—endorsed Clay for President and Fillmore for Governor,
1844.

> The Democrats represented a wide range of views but shared a fundamental
> commitment to the Jeffersonian concept of an agrarian society. They viewed
> the central government as the enemy of individual liberty. The 1824 "corrupt
> bargain" had strengthened their suspicion of Washington politics. ...
> Jacksonians feared the concentration of economic and political power. They
> believed that government intervention in the economy benefited special-
> interest groups and created corporate monopolies that favored the rich. They
> sought to restore the independence of the individual (the "common man," i.e.
> the artisan and the ordinary farmer) by ending federal support of banks and
> corporations and restricting the use of paper currency, which they
> distrusted. Their definition of the proper role of government tended to be
> negative, and Jackson's political power was largely expressed in negative
> acts. He exercised the veto more than all previous presidents combined.
> Jackson and his supporters also opposed reform as a movement. Reformers
> eager to turn their programs into legislation called for a more active
> government. But Democrats tended to oppose programs like educational reform
> mid the establishment of a public education system. They believed, for
> instance, that public schools restricted individual liberty by interfering
> with parental responsibility and undermined freedom of religion by replacing
> church schools. Nor did Jackson share reformers' humanitarian concerns. He
> had no sympathy for American Indians, initiating the removal of the
> Cherokees along the Trail of Tears.[86][87]

### Second Great
Awakening[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Second Great Awakening")]

Main article: [Second Great Awakening](/wiki/Second_Great_Awakening "Second
Great Awakening")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Camp_meeting.jpg/200px-
Camp_meeting.jpg)](/wiki/File:Camp_meeting.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Camp_meeting.jpg "Enlarge")

A drawing of a Protestant camp meeting, 1829.

The Second Great Awakening was a Protestant revival movement that affected the
entire nation during the early 19th century and led to rapid church growth.
The movement began around 1790, gained momentum by 1800, and, after 1820
membership rose rapidly among Baptist and Methodist congregations, whose
preachers led the movement. It was past its peak by the 1840s.[88]

It enrolled millions of new members in existing evangelical denominations and
led to the formation of new denominations. Many converts believed that the
Awakening heralded a new [millennial age](/wiki/Millennialism
"Millennialism"). The Second Great Awakening stimulated the establishment of
many reform movements – including
[abolitionism](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the
United States") and [temperance](/wiki/Temperance_movement "Temperance
movement") designed to remove the evils of society before the anticipated
[Second Coming](/wiki/Second_Coming "Second Coming") of Jesus Christ.[89]

###
Abolitionism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Abolitionism")]

Main article: [Abolitionism in the United
States](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the United
States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/69th_New_York_at_church.jpg/220px-69th_New_York_at_church.jpg)](/wiki/File:69th_New_York_at_church.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:69th_New_York_at_church.jpg "Enlarge")

Officers and men of the [Irish-Catholic](/wiki/Irish-Catholic "Irish-
Catholic") [69th New York Volunteer
Regiment](/wiki/69th_Infantry_Regiment_\(New_York\) "69th Infantry Regiment
\(New York\)") attend Catholic services in 1861.

After 1840 the abolitionist movement redefined itself as a crusade against the
sin of slave ownership. It mobilized support (especially among religious women
in the Northeast affected by the [Second Great
Awakening](/wiki/Second_Great_Awakening "Second Great Awakening")). [William
Lloyd Garrison](/wiki/William_Lloyd_Garrison "William Lloyd Garrison"), a
radical abolitionist, published the most influential of the many anti-slavery
newspapers, _[The Liberator](/wiki/The_Liberator_\(anti-slavery_newspaper\)
"The Liberator \(anti-slavery newspaper\)")_ , while [Frederick
Douglass](/wiki/Frederick_Douglass "Frederick Douglass"), an ex-slave, began
writing for that newspaper around 1840 and started his own abolitionist
newspaper _[North Star](/wiki/North_Star_\(newspaper\) "North Star
\(newspaper\)")_ in 1847.[90] The great majority of anti-slavery activists,
such as Abraham Lincoln, rejected Garrison's theology and held that slavery
was an unfortunate social evil, not a sin.[91][92]

### Westward expansion and Manifest
Destiny[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Westward expansion and Manifest Destiny")]

Main article: [American frontier](/wiki/American_frontier "American frontier")

The American colonies and the new nation grew rapidly in population and area,
as pioneers pushed the frontier of settlement west.[93] The process finally
ended around 1890–1912 as the last major farmlands and ranch lands were
settled. Native American tribes in some places resisted militarily, but they
were overwhelmed by settlers and the army and after 1830 were relocated to
reservations in the west. The highly influential "[Frontier
Thesis](/wiki/Frontier_Thesis "Frontier Thesis")" of Wisconsin historian
[Frederick Jackson Turner](/wiki/Frederick_Jackson_Turner "Frederick Jackson
Turner") argues that the frontier shaped the national character, with its
boldness, violence, innovation, [individualism](/wiki/Individualism
"Individualism"), and democracy.[94]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/1850_Woman_and_Men_in_California_Gold_Rush.jpg/250px-1850_Woman_and_Men_in_California_Gold_Rush.jpg)](/wiki/File:1850_Woman_and_Men_in_California_Gold_Rush.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:1850_Woman_and_Men_in_California_Gold_Rush.jpg "Enlarge")

The [California Gold Rush](/wiki/California_Gold_Rush "California Gold Rush")
news of gold brought some 300,000 people to California from the rest of the
United States and abroad.

Recent historians have emphasized the multicultural nature of the frontier.
Enormous popular attention in the media focuses on the "Wild West" of the
second half of the 19th century. As defined by Hine and Faragher, "frontier
history tells the story of the creation and defense of communities, the use of
the land, the development of markets, and the formation of states". They
explain, "It is a tale of conquest, but also one of survival, persistence, and
the merging of peoples and cultures that gave birth and continuing life to
America."[94] The first settlers in the west were the Spanish in New Mexico;
they became U.S. citizens in 1848. The Hispanics in California
("[Californios](/wiki/Californios "Californios")") were overwhelmed by over
100,000 gold rush miners. California grew explosively. San Francisco by 1880
had become the economic hub of the entire Pacific Coast with a diverse
population of a quarter million.

From the early 1830s to 1869, the [Oregon Trail](/wiki/Oregon_Trail "Oregon
Trail") and its many offshoots were used by over 300,000 settlers. '49ers (in
the [California Gold Rush](/wiki/California_Gold_Rush "California Gold
Rush")), ranchers, farmers, and entrepreneurs and their families headed to
California, Oregon, and other points in the far west. Wagon-trains took five
or six months on foot; after 1869, the trip took 6 days by rail.[95]

[Manifest Destiny](/wiki/Manifest_destiny "Manifest destiny") was the belief
that American settlers were destined to expand across the continent. This
concept was born out of "A sense of mission to redeem the Old World by high
example ... generated by the potentialities of a new earth for building a new
heaven."[96] Manifest Destiny was rejected by modernizers, especially the
Whigs like Henry Clay and Abraham Lincoln who wanted to build cities and
factories – not more farms.[97]
[Democrats](/wiki/History_of_the_Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "History
of the Democratic Party \(United States\)") strongly favored expansion, and
won the key election of 1844. After a bitter debate in Congress the [Republic
of Texas was annexed](/wiki/Texas_Annexation "Texas Annexation") in 1845,
leading to war with Mexico, who considered Texas to be a part of Mexico due to
the large numbers of Mexican settlers.[98]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Mexico_nebel.jpg/250px-
Mexico_nebel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mexico_nebel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mexico_nebel.jpg "Enlarge")

The American occupation of [Mexico City](/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City") in
1848

The [Mexican–American War](/wiki/Mexican%E2%80%93American_War
"Mexican–American War") (1846–48) broke out with the Whigs opposed to the war,
and the Democrats supporting the war. The U.S. army, using regulars and large
numbers of volunteers, defeated the Mexican armies, invaded at several points,
captured Mexico City and won decisively. The [Treaty of Guadalupe
Hidalgo](/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe_Hidalgo "Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo")
ended the war in 1848. Many Democrats wanted to annex all of Mexico, but that
idea was rejected by southerners who argued that by incorporating millions of
Mexican people, mainly of mixed race, would undermine the United States as an
exclusively white republic.[99] Instead the U.S. took Texas and the lightly
settled northern parts (California and New Mexico). The Hispanic residents
were given full citizenship and the [Mexican
Indians](/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_Mexico "Indigenous peoples of Mexico")
became [American Indians](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States"). Simultaneously, gold was discovered in
California in 1849, attracting over 100,000 men to northern California in a
matter of months in the [California Gold Rush](/wiki/California_Gold_Rush
"California Gold Rush"). A peaceful compromise with Britain gave the U.S.
ownership of the [Oregon Country](/wiki/Oregon_Country "Oregon Country"),
which was renamed the [Oregon Territory](/wiki/Oregon_Territory "Oregon
Territory").[98]

### Divisions between North and
South[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Divisions between North and South")]

Main articles: [Origins of the American Civil
War](/wiki/Origins_of_the_American_Civil_War "Origins of the American Civil
War") and [History of the United States
(1849–65)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1849%E2%80%9365\) "History of
the United States \(1849–65\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/US_Secession_map_1863_%28BlankMap_derived%29.png/250px-
US_Secession_map_1863_%28BlankMap_derived%29.png)](/wiki/File:US_Secession_map_1863_\(BlankMap_derived\).png)

[](/wiki/File:US_Secession_map_1863_\(BlankMap_derived\).png "Enlarge")

United States map, 1863

Union states

Union territories not permitting slavery

Border Union states, permitting slavery

Confederate states

Union territories permitting slavery (claimed by Confederacy)

The central issue after 1848 was the expansion of slavery, pitting the anti-
slavery elements in the North, against the pro-slavery elements that dominated
the South. A small number of active Northerners were
[abolitionists](/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States "Abolitionism in the
United States") who declared that ownership of slaves was a sin (in terms of
Protestant theology) and demanded its immediate abolition. Much larger numbers
in the North were against the expansion of slavery, seeking to put it on the
path to extinction so that America would be committed to free land (as in low-
cost farms owned and cultivated by a family), free labor, and free speech (as
opposed to censorship of abolitionist material in the South). Southern whites
insisted that slavery was of economic, social, and cultural benefit to all
whites (and even to the slaves themselves), and denounced all anti-slavery
spokesmen as "abolitionists."[100] Justifications of slavery included
economics, history, religion, legality, social good, and even humanitarianism,
to further their arguments. Defenders of slavery argued that the sudden end to
the slave economy would have had a profound and killing economic impact in the
South where reliance on slave labor was the foundation of their economy. They
also argued that if all the slaves were freed, there would be widespread
unemployment and chaos.[101]

Religious activists split on slavery, with the Methodists and Baptists
dividing into northern and southern denominations. In the North, the
Methodists, Congregationalists, and Quakers included many abolitionists,
especially among women activists. (The Catholic, Episcopal and Lutheran
denominations largely ignored the slavery issue.)[102]

The issue of slavery in the new territories was seemingly settled by the
[Compromise of 1850](/wiki/Compromise_of_1850 "Compromise of 1850"), brokered
by Whig [Henry Clay](/wiki/Henry_Clay "Henry Clay") and Democrat [Stephen
Douglas](/wiki/Stephen_Douglas "Stephen Douglas"); the Compromise included the
admission of California as a [free state](/wiki/Free_state_\(United_States\)
"Free state \(United States\)") in exchange for no federal restrictions on
slavery placed on Utah or New Mexico.[103] The point of contention was the
[Fugitive Slave Act](/wiki/Fugitive_Slave_Act "Fugitive Slave Act"), which
increased federal enforcement and required even free states to cooperate in
turning over fugitive slaves to their owners. Abolitionists pounced on the Act
to attack slavery, as in the best-selling anti-slavery [novel](/wiki/Novel
"Novel") _[Uncle Tom's Cabin](/wiki/Uncle_Tom%27s_Cabin "Uncle Tom's Cabin")_
by [Harriet Beecher Stowe](/wiki/Harriet_Beecher_Stowe "Harriet Beecher
Stowe").[104]

The [Compromise of 1820](/wiki/Compromise_of_1820 "Compromise of 1820") was
repealed in 1854 with the [Kansas–Nebraska
Act](/wiki/Kansas%E2%80%93Nebraska_Act "Kansas–Nebraska Act"), promoted by
Senator Douglas in the name of "[popular
sovereignty](/wiki/Popular_sovereignty_in_the_United_States "Popular
sovereignty in the United States")" and democracy. It permitted voters to
decide on the legality slavery in each territory, and allowed Douglas to adopt
neutrality on the issue of slavery. Anti-slavery forces rose in anger and
alarm, forming the new [Republican
Party](/wiki/History_of_the_Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "History of the
Republican Party \(United States\)"). Pro- and anti- contingents rushed to
Kansas to vote slavery up or down, resulting in a miniature civil war called
[Bleeding Kansas](/wiki/Bleeding_Kansas "Bleeding Kansas"). By the late 1850s,
the young Republican Party dominated nearly all northern states and thus the
electoral college. It insisted that slavery would never be allowed to expand
(and thus would slowly die out).[105]

The Southern slavery-based societies had become wealthy based on their
[cotton](/wiki/Cotton "Cotton") and other agricultural
[commodity](/wiki/Commodity "Commodity") production, and some particularly
profited from the internal slave trade. Northern cities such as Boston and New
York, and regional industries, were tied economically to slavery by banking,
shipping, and manufacturing, including [textile mills](/wiki/Textile_mills
"Textile mills"). By 1860, there were four million slaves in [the
South](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United States"), nearly eight
times as many as there were nationwide in 1790. The
[plantations](/wiki/Plantations_in_the_American_South "Plantations in the
American South") were highly profitable, due to the heavy European demand for
raw cotton. Most of the profits were invested in new lands and in purchasing
more slaves (largely drawn from the declining [tobacco](/wiki/Tobacco
"Tobacco") regions).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/National-
atlas-1970-1860.png/300px-National-atlas-1970-1860.png)](/wiki/File:National-
atlas-1970-1860.png)

[](/wiki/File:National-atlas-1970-1860.png "Enlarge")

The United States, immediately before the Civil War. All of the lands east of,
or bordering, the Mississippi River were organized as states in the Union, but
the West was still largely unsettled.

For 50 of the nation's first 72 years, a slaveholder served as President of
the United States and, during that period, only slaveholding presidents were
re-elected to second terms.[106] In addition, southern states benefited by
their increased apportionment in Congress due to the partial counting of
slaves in their populations.

Slave rebellions, by [Gabriel Prosser](/wiki/Gabriel_Prosser "Gabriel
Prosser") (1800), [Denmark Vesey](/wiki/Denmark_Vesey "Denmark Vesey") (1822),
[Nat Turner](/wiki/Nat_Turner "Nat Turner") (1831), and most famously by [John
Brown](/wiki/John_Brown%27s_raid_on_Harpers_Ferry "John Brown's raid on
Harpers Ferry") (1859), caused fear in the white South, which imposed stricter
oversight of slaves and reduced the rights of [free
blacks](/wiki/Free_people_of_color "Free people of color"). The Fugitive Slave
Act of 1850 required the states to cooperate with slave owners when attempting
to recover escaped slaves, which outraged Northerners. Formerly, an escaped
slave that reached a non-slave state was presumed to have attained sanctuary
and freedom under the [Missouri Compromise](/wiki/Missouri_Compromise
"Missouri Compromise"). The Supreme Court's 1857 decision in _[Dred Scott v.
Sandford](/wiki/Dred_Scott_v._Sandford "Dred Scott v. Sandford")_ ruled that
the Missouri Compromise was unconstitutional; angry Republicans said this
decision threatened to make slavery a national institution.

After [Abraham Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") won the [1860
election](/wiki/1860_presidential_election "1860 presidential election"),
seven Southern states [seceded](/wiki/Secession "Secession") from the union
and set up a new nation, the [Confederate States of
America](/wiki/Confederate_States_of_America "Confederate States of America")
(Confederacy), on February 8, 1861. It attacked [Fort
Sumter](/wiki/Fort_Sumter "Fort Sumter"), a U.S. Army fort in South Carolina,
thus igniting the war. When Lincoln called for troops to suppress the
Confederacy in April 1861, four more states seceded and joined the
Confederacy. A few of the (northernmost) "[slave
states](/wiki/Slave_and_free_states "Slave and free states")" did not secede
and became known as the [border
states](/wiki/Border_states_\(American_Civil_War\) "Border states \(American
Civil War\)"); these were Delaware, Maryland, Kentucky, and Missouri.

During the war, the northwestern portion of Virginia seceded from the
Confederacy. and became the new Union state of [West
Virginia](/wiki/West_Virginia "West Virginia").[107] West Virginia is usually
associated with the [border states](/wiki/Border_states_\(American_Civil_War\)
"Border states \(American Civil War\)").

### Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Civil War")]

Main article: [American Civil War](/wiki/American_Civil_War "American Civil
War")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Advantages.jpg/250px-
Advantages.jpg)](/wiki/File:Advantages.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Advantages.jpg "Enlarge")

The Union had large advantages in men and resources at the start of the war.
The ratio grew steadily in favor of the Union.

The Civil War began on April 12, 1861, when elements of 100,000 [Confederate
forces attacked a U.S. military installation](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Sumter
"Battle of Fort Sumter") at [Fort Sumter](/wiki/Fort_Sumter "Fort Sumter") in
[South Carolina](/wiki/South_Carolina "South Carolina"). In response to the
attack, on April 15, Lincoln called on the states to send detachments totaling
75,000 troops to recapture forts, protect the capital, and "preserve the
Union", which in his view still existed intact despite the actions of the
seceding states. The two armies had their first major clash at the [First
Battle of Bull Run](/wiki/First_Battle_of_Bull_Run "First Battle of Bull Run")
(Battle of Manassas), ending in a Union defeat, but, more importantly, proved
to both the Union and Confederacy that the war would be much longer and
bloodier than originally anticipated.[108]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/PinkertonLincolnMcClernand.jpg/250px-
PinkertonLincolnMcClernand.jpg)](/wiki/File:PinkertonLincolnMcClernand.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:PinkertonLincolnMcClernand.jpg "Enlarge")

Lincoln with [Allan Pinkerton](/wiki/Allan_Pinkerton "Allan Pinkerton") and
Major General [John Alexander McClernand](/wiki/John_Alexander_McClernand
"John Alexander McClernand") at the [Battle of
Antietam](/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam "Battle of Antietam").

The war soon divided into two theaters:
[Eastern](/wiki/Eastern_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Eastern Theater of
the American Civil War") and
[Western](/wiki/Western_Theater_of_the_American_Civil_War "Western Theater of
the American Civil War"). In the western theater, the Union was relatively
successful, with major battles, such as
[Perryville](/wiki/Battle_of_Perryville "Battle of Perryville") and
[Shiloh](/wiki/Battle_of_Shiloh "Battle of Shiloh") along with Union gunboat
dominance of navigable rivers producing strategic Union victories and
destroying major Confederate operations.[109]

Warfare in the Eastern theater began poorly for the Union as the Confederates
won at Manassas Junction (Bull Run), just outside Washington. Major General
[George B. McClellan](/wiki/George_B._McClellan "George B. McClellan") was put
in charge of the Union armies. After reorganizing the new [Army of the
Potomac](/wiki/Army_of_the_Potomac "Army of the Potomac"), McClellan failed to
capture the Confederate capital of [Richmond,
Virginia](/wiki/Richmond,_Virginia "Richmond, Virginia") in his [Peninsula
Campaign](/wiki/Peninsula_Campaign "Peninsula Campaign") and [retreated after
attacks](/wiki/Seven_Days_Battle "Seven Days Battle") from newly appointed
Confederate General [Robert E. Lee](/wiki/Robert_E._Lee "Robert E. Lee").[110]
Meanwhile, both sides concentrated in 1861–62 on raising and training new
armies. The main action was Union success in controlling the border states,
with Confederates largely driven out of Maryland, West Virginia (a new state),
Kentucky and Missouri. The autumn 1862 Confederate campaign into Maryland was
designed to hurt Union morale and win European support. It ended with
Confederate retreat at the [Battle of Antietam](/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam
"Battle of Antietam"), and Lincoln's warning he would issue an Emancipation
Proclamation in January 1863 if the states did not return. Making slavery a
central war goal Energized Republicans in the North, as well as their enemies,
the anti-war Copperhead Democrats. It ended the risk of British and French
intervention.

Lee's smaller army won at the [Battle of
Fredericksburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Fredericksburg "Battle of Fredericksburg")
late in 1862, causing yet another change in commanders. Lee won again at the
[Battle of Chancellorsville](/wiki/Battle_of_Chancellorsville "Battle of
Chancellorsville") in May 1863, while losing his top aide, [Stonewall
Jackson](/wiki/Stonewall_Jackson "Stonewall Jackson"). But Lee pushed too hard
and ignored the Union threat in the west. Lee invaded Pennsylvania in search
of supplies and to cause [war-weariness](/wiki/War-weariness "War-weariness")
in the North. In perhaps the [turning point of the
war](/wiki/Turning_point_of_the_American_Civil_War "Turning point of the
American Civil War"), Lee's army was badly beaten at the [Battle of
Gettysburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Gettysburg "Battle of Gettysburg"), July 1–3,
1863, and barely made it back to Virginia.[111] On the homefront, industrial
expansion in the North expanded dramatically, using its extensive railroad
service, and moving industrial workers into munitions factories. Foreign trade
increased, with the United States providing both food and cotton to Britain,
And Britain sending in manufactured products and thousands of volunteers for
the Union Army (plus a few to the Confederates). The British operated blockade
runners bringing in food, luxury items and munitions to the Confederacy,
bringing out tobacco and cotton. The Union blockade increasingly shut down
Confederate ports, and by late 1864 the blockade runners Were usually captured
before they could make more than handful of runs.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Kurz_and_Allison_-
_Battle_of_Franklin%2C_November_30%2C_1864.jpg/300px-Kurz_and_Allison_-
_Battle_of_Franklin%2C_November_30%2C_1864.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kurz_and_Allison_-
_Battle_of_Franklin,_November_30,_1864.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kurz_and_Allison_-_Battle_of_Franklin,_November_30,_1864.jpg
"Enlarge")

The [Battle of Franklin](/wiki/Battle_of_Franklin "Battle of Franklin"),
November 30, 1864.

In the West, on July 4, 1863, Union forces under the command of General
[Ulysses S. Grant](/wiki/Ulysses_S._Grant "Ulysses S. Grant") gained control
of the Mississippi River at the [Battle of
Vicksburg](/wiki/Battle_of_Vicksburg "Battle of Vicksburg"), thereby splitting
the Confederacy. Lincoln made General Grant commander of all Union armies.
Grant put General William Tecumseh Sherman in charge of the Western armies. In
1864, Sherman marched south from Chattanooga to capture Atlanta, a decisive
victory that ended war jitters among Republicans in the North who feared they
might fail to reelect Lincoln in 1864. Lincoln won a landslide. The last two
years of the war were bloody for both sides, With Sherman marching almost
unopposed through central and eastern Georgia, then moving up through South
Carolina and North Carolina, burning cities, destroying plantations, ruining
railroads and bridges, but avoiding civilian casualties. Sherman demonstrated
that the South line the long-term ability to resist a northern invasion. Much
of the heartland of the Confederacy was physically destroyed, and could no
longer provide desperately needed food, horses, mules, wagons, boots or
munitions to its combat armies. In spring 1864 Grant, realizing that Lee was
unable to replenishes casualties, while Lincoln would provide replacements for
Union losses, launched a [war of attrition](/wiki/Attrition_warfare "Attrition
warfare") against Lee's [Army of Northern
Virginia](/wiki/Army_of_Northern_Virginia "Army of Northern Virginia"). This
war of attrition was divided into three main campaigns. The first of these,
the [Overland Campaign](/wiki/Overland_Campaign "Overland Campaign") forced
Lee to retreat into the city of Petersburg where Grant launched his second
major offensive, the [Richmond-Petersburg Campaign](/wiki/Richmond-
Petersburg_Campaign "Richmond-Petersburg Campaign") in which he [besieged
Petersburg](/wiki/Siege_of_Petersburg "Siege of Petersburg"). After a near
ten-month siege, Petersburg surrendered. However, the [defense of Fort
Gregg](/wiki/Third_Battle_of_Petersburg "Third Battle of Petersburg") allowed
Lee to move his army out of Petersburg. Grant pursued and launched the final,
[Appomattox Campaign](/wiki/Appomattox_Campaign "Appomattox Campaign") which
resulted in Lee surrendering his Army of Northern Virginia numbering 28,000 on
April 9, 1865, at [Appomattox Court
House](/wiki/Appomattox_Court_House_National_Historical_Park "Appomattox Court
House National Historical Park"). Other Confederate armies followed suit and
the war ended with no postwar insurgency.

The American Civil War was the world's earliest [industrial
war](/wiki/Industrial_warfare "Industrial warfare"). Railroads, the telegraph,
steamships, and mass-produced weapons were employed extensively. The
mobilization of civilian factories, mines, shipyards, banks, transportation
and food supplies all foreshadowed the impact of industrialization in [World
War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"). It remains the deadliest war in
American history, resulting in the deaths of about 750,000 soldiers and an
undetermined number of [civilian casualties](/wiki/Civilian_casualties
"Civilian casualties").[112] About ten percent of all Northern males 20–45
years old, and 30 percent of all Southern white males aged 18–40 died.[113]
Its legacy includes ending slavery in the United States, restoring the Union,
and strengthening the role of the federal government.

According to historian [Allan Nevins](/wiki/Allan_Nevins "Allan Nevins") the
Civil War had a major long-term impact on the United States in terms of
developing its leadership potential and moving the entire nation beyond the
adolescent stage:

    The fighting and its attendant demands upon industry, finance, medicine, and law also helped train a host of leaders who during the next 35 years, to 1900, made their influence powerfully felt on most of the social, economic, and cultural fronts. It broke down barriers of parochialism; it ended distrust of large-scale effort; it hardened and matured the whole people emotionally. The adolescent land of the 1850s…rose under the blows of battle to adult estate. The nation of the post-Appomattox generation, though sadly hurt (especially in the South) by war losses, and deeply scarred psychologically (especially in the North) by war hatreds and greeds, had at last the power, resolution, and self-trust of manhood.[114]

![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Emancipation_proclamation.jpg/300px-
Emancipation_proclamation.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Emancipation_proclamation.jpg "Enlarge")

_[First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation of President

The [Emancipation Proclamation](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation
Proclamation") was an executive order issued by President [Abraham
Lincoln](/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") on January 1, 1863. In a
single stroke it changed the legal status, as recognized by the U.S.
government, of 3 million slaves in designated areas of the Confederacy from
"slave" to "free." It had the practical effect that as soon as a slave escaped
the control of the Confederate government, by running away or through advances
of federal troops, the slave became legally and actually free. The owners were
never compensated. Plantation owners, realizing that emancipation would
destroy their economic system, sometimes moved their slaves as far as possible
out of reach of the Union army. By June 1865, the Union Army controlled all of
the Confederacy and liberated all of the designated slaves.[116] Large numbers
moved into camps run by the [Freedmen's Bureau](/wiki/Freedmen%27s_Bureau
"Freedmen's Bureau"), where they were given food, shelter, medical care, and
arrangements for their employment were made.

The severe dislocations of war and Reconstruction had a large negative impact
on the black population, with a large amount of sickness and death.[117]

### Reconstruction
Era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Reconstruction Era")]

Main article: [Reconstruction Era](/wiki/Reconstruction_Era "Reconstruction
Era")

See also: [History of the United States
(1865–1918)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1865%E2%80%931918\) "History
of the United States \(1865–1918\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/FreedmenVotingInNewOrleans1867.jpeg/300px-
FreedmenVotingInNewOrleans1867.jpeg)](/wiki/File:FreedmenVotingInNewOrleans1867.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:FreedmenVotingInNewOrleans1867.jpeg "Enlarge")

[Freedmen](/wiki/Freedman "Freedman") voting in New Orleans, 1867.

Reconstruction lasted from Lincoln's [Emancipation
Proclamation](/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation "Emancipation Proclamation") of
January 1, 1863 to the [Compromise of 1877](/wiki/Compromise_of_1877
"Compromise of 1877").[118]

The major issues faced by Lincoln were the status of the ex-slaves (called
"Freedmen"), the loyalty and civil rights of ex-rebels, the status of the 11
ex-Confederate states, the powers of the federal government needed to prevent
a future civil war, and the question of whether Congress or the President
would make the major decisions.

The severe threats of starvation and displacement of the unemployed Freedmen
were met by the first major federal relief agency, the [Freedmen's
Bureau](/wiki/Freedmen%27s_Bureau "Freedmen's Bureau"), operated by the
Army.[119]

Three "[Reconstruction Amendments](/wiki/Reconstruction_Amendments
"Reconstruction Amendments")" were passed to expand civil rights for black
Americans: the [Thirteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Thirteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Thirteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") outlawed slavery;
the [Fourteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fourteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") guaranteed equal
rights for all and citizenship for blacks; the [Fifteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Fifteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Fifteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") prevented race from
being used to disfranchise men.

Ex-Confederates remained in control of most Southern states for over two
years, but changed when the [Radical Republicans](/wiki/Radical_Republicans
"Radical Republicans") gained control of Congress in the 1866 elections.
President [Andrew Johnson](/wiki/Andrew_Johnson "Andrew Johnson"), who sought
easy terms for reunions with ex-rebels, was virtually powerless in the face of
the Radical Republican Congress; he was impeached, but the Senate's attempt to
remove him from office failed by one vote. Congress enfranchised black men and
temporarily stripped many ex-Confederate leaders of the right to hold office.
New Republican governments came to power based on a coalition of Freedmen made
up of [Carpetbaggers](/wiki/Carpetbaggers "Carpetbaggers") (new arrivals from
the North), and [Scalawags](/wiki/Scalawags "Scalawags") (native white
Southerners). They were backed by the U.S. Army. Opponents said they were
corrupt and violated the rights of whites.[120]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Atlanta_roundhouse_ruin3.jpg/250px-
Atlanta_roundhouse_ruin3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Atlanta_roundhouse_ruin3.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Atlanta_roundhouse_ruin3.jpg "Enlarge")

Atlanta's railyard and roundhouse in ruins shortly after the end of the Civil
War

State by state they lost power to a conservative-Democratic coalition, which
gained control of the entire South by 1877. In response to Radical
Reconstruction, the [Ku Klux Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku Klux Klan") (KKK)
emerged in 1867 as a white-supremacist organization opposed to black civil
rights and Republican rule. President Ulysses Grant's vigorous enforcement of
the [Ku Klux Klan Act](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan_Act "Ku Klux Klan Act") of 1870 shut
down the Klan, and it disbanded. [Paramilitary](/wiki/Paramilitary
"Paramilitary") groups, such as the [White League](/wiki/White_League "White
League") and [Red Shirts](/wiki/Red_Shirts_\(Southern_United_States\) "Red
Shirts \(Southern United States\)") emerged about 1874 that worked openly to
use intimidation and violence to suppress black voting to regain white
political power in states across the South during the 1870s. Rable described
them as the military arm of the Democratic Party.[120]

Reconstruction ended after the disputed [1876
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1876 "United States
presidential election, 1876"). The [Compromise of
1877](/wiki/Compromise_of_1877 "Compromise of 1877") gave Republican candidate
[Rutherford B. Hayes](/wiki/Rutherford_B._Hayes "Rutherford B. Hayes") the
White House in exchange for removing all remaining federal troops in the
South. The federal government withdrew its troops from the South, and Southern
Democrats took control of every Southern state.[121] From 1890 to 1908,
southern states effectively
[disfranchised](/wiki/Disfranchisement_after_Reconstruction_era
"Disfranchisement after Reconstruction era") most black voters and many poor
whites by making voter registration more difficult through [poll
taxes](/wiki/Poll_tax_\(United_States\) "Poll tax \(United States\)"),
[literacy tests](/wiki/Literacy_test "Literacy test"), and other arbitrary
devices. They passed segregation laws and imposed second-class status on
blacks in a system known as [Jim Crow](/wiki/Jim_Crow_Laws "Jim Crow Laws")
that lasted until the [Civil Rights Movement](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement
"Civil Rights Movement").[122][123]

### The West and the Gilded
Age[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: The West and the Gilded Age")]

Main article: [Gilded Age](/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/East_and_West_Shaking_hands_at_the_laying_of_last_rail_Union_Pacific_Railroad_-
_Restoration.jpg/300px-
East_and_West_Shaking_hands_at_the_laying_of_last_rail_Union_Pacific_Railroad_-
_Restoration.jpg)](/wiki/File:East_and_West_Shaking_hands_at_the_laying_of_last_rail_Union_Pacific_Railroad_-
_Restoration.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:East_and_West_Shaking_hands_at_the_laying_of_last_rail_Union_Pacific_Railroad_-
_Restoration.jpg "Enlarge")

The completion of the Transcontinental Railroad (1869) at [First
Transcontinental Railroad](/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad "First
Transcontinental Railroad"), by Andrew J. Russell.

The latter half of the nineteenth century was marked by the rapid development
and settlement of the far West, first by wagon trains and riverboats and then
aided by the completion of the [transcontinental
railroad](/wiki/Transcontinental_railroad "Transcontinental railroad"). Large
numbers of European immigrants (especially from Germany and Scandinavia) took
up low-cost or free farms in the Prairie States. Mining for silver and copper
opened up the Mountain West. The United States Army fought frequent small-
scale wars with Native Americans as settlers encroached on their traditional
lands. Gradually the U.S. purchased the Native American tribal lands and
extinguished their claims, forcing most tribes onto subsidized
[reservations](/wiki/Indian_reservation "Indian reservation"). According to
the [U.S. Bureau of the Census](/wiki/U.S._Bureau_of_the_Census "U.S. Bureau
of the Census") (1894), from 1789 to 1894:

> The [Indian wars](/wiki/American_Indian_Wars "American Indian Wars") under
> the government of the United States have been more than 40 in number. They
> have cost the lives of about 19,000 white men, women and children, including
> those killed in individual combats, and the lives of about 30,000 Indians.
> The actual number of killed and wounded Indians must be very much higher
> than the given... Fifty percent additional would be a safe estimate...[124]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Andrew_Carnegie%2C_three-
quarter_length_portrait%2C_seated%2C_facing_slightly_left%2C_1913.jpg/180px-
Andrew_Carnegie%2C_three-
quarter_length_portrait%2C_seated%2C_facing_slightly_left%2C_1913.jpg)](/wiki/File:Andrew_Carnegie,_three-
quarter_length_portrait,_seated,_facing_slightly_left,_1913.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Andrew_Carnegie,_three-
quarter_length_portrait,_seated,_facing_slightly_left,_1913.jpg "Enlarge")

Scottish immigrant [Andrew Carnegie](/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie")
led the enormous expansion of the American steel industry.

The "Gilded Age" was a term that [Mark Twain](/wiki/Mark_Twain "Mark Twain")
used to describe the period of the late 19th century with a dramatic expansion
of American wealth and prosperity, underscored by the mass corruption in the
government. Reforms of the Age included the [Civil Service
Act](/wiki/Pendleton_Civil_Service_Reform_Act "Pendleton Civil Service Reform
Act"), which mandated a competitive examination for applicants for government
jobs. Other important legislation included the [Interstate Commerce
Act](/wiki/Interstate_Commerce_Act "Interstate Commerce Act"), which ended
railroads' discrimination against small shippers, and the [Sherman Antitrust
Act](/wiki/Sherman_Antitrust_Act "Sherman Antitrust Act"), which outlawed
monopolies in business. Twain believed that this age was corrupted by such
elements as land speculators, scandalous politics, and unethical business
practices.[125] Since the days of [Charles A. Beard](/wiki/Charles_A._Beard
"Charles A. Beard") and [Matthew Josephson](/wiki/Matthew_Josephson "Matthew
Josephson"), some historians have argued that the United States was
effectively [plutocratic](/wiki/Plutocratic "Plutocratic") for at least part
of the [Gilded Age](/wiki/Gilded_Age "Gilded Age") and [Progressive
Era](/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive Era").[126][127][128][129][130] As
financiers and industrialists such as [J.P. Morgan](/wiki/J.P._Morgan "J.P.
Morgan") and [John D. Rockefeller](/wiki/John_D._Rockefeller "John D.
Rockefeller") began to amass vast fortunes, many U.S. observers were concerned
that the nation was losing its pioneering egalitarian spirit.[131]

By 1890 American industrial production and per capita income exceeded those of
all other world nations. In response to heavy debts and decreasing farm
prices, wheat and cotton farmers joined the [Populist
Party](/wiki/People%27s_Party_\(United_States\) "People's Party \(United
States\)").[132] An unprecedented wave of
[immigration](/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States "Immigration to the
United States") from Europe served to both provide the labor for American
industry and create diverse communities in previously undeveloped areas. From
1880 to 1914, peak years of immigration, more than 22 million people migrated
to the United States.[133] Most were unskilled workers who quickly found jobs
in mines, mills, factories. Many immigrants were craftsmen (especially from
Britain and Germany) bringing human skills, and others were farmers
(especially from Germany and Scandinavia) who purchased inexpensive land on
the Prairies from railroads who sent agents to Europe. Poverty, growing
inequality and dangerous working conditions, along with
[socialist](/wiki/History_of_the_socialist_movement_in_the_United_States
"History of the socialist movement in the United States") and
[anarchist](/wiki/Anarchism_in_the_United_States "Anarchism in the United
States") ideas diffusing from European immigrants, led to the rise of the
[labor movement](/wiki/Labor_history_of_the_United_States "Labor history of
the United States"), which often included violent strikes.[134][135]

Skilled workers banded together to control their crafts and raise wages by
forming labor unions in industrial areas of the Northeast. Before the 1930s
few factory workers joined the [unions in the labor
movement](/wiki/Labor_history_of_the_United_States "Labor history of the
United States"). [Samuel Gompers](/wiki/Samuel_Gompers "Samuel Gompers") led
the [American Federation of Labor](/wiki/American_Federation_of_Labor
"American Federation of Labor") (1886–1924), coordinating multiple unions.
Industrial growth was rapid, led by [John D.
Rockefeller](/wiki/John_D._Rockefeller "John D. Rockefeller") in oil and
[Andrew Carnegie](/wiki/Andrew_Carnegie "Andrew Carnegie") in steel; both
became leaders of philanthropy ([Gospel of Wealth](/wiki/The_Gospel_of_Wealth
"The Gospel of Wealth")), giving away their fortunes to create the modern
system of hospitals, universities, libraries, and foundations.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg/250px-
Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mulberry_Street_NYC_c1900_LOC_3g04637u_edit.jpg "Enlarge")

Mulberry Street, along which Manhattan's [Little
Italy](/wiki/Little_Italy,_Manhattan "Little Italy, Manhattan") is centered.
[Lower East Side](/wiki/Lower_East_Side,_Manhattan "Lower East Side,
Manhattan"), circa 1900. Almost 97% of residents of the 10 largest American
cities of 1900 were non-Hispanic whites.[136]

The [Panic of 1893](/wiki/Panic_of_1893 "Panic of 1893") broke out and was a
severe nationwide depression impacting farmers, workers, and businessmen who
saw prices, wages, and profits fall.[137] Many railroads went bankrupt. The
resultant political reaction fell on the Democratic Party, whose leader
President [Grover Cleveland](/wiki/Grover_Cleveland "Grover Cleveland")
shouldered much of the blame. Labor unrest involved numerous strikes, most
notably the violent [Pullman Strike](/wiki/Pullman_Strike "Pullman Strike") of
1894, which was shut down by federal troops under Cleveland's orders. The
[Populist Party](/wiki/People%27s_Party_\(United_States\) "People's Party
\(United States\)") gained strength among cotton and wheat farmers, as well as
coal miners, but was overtaken by the even more popular [Free
Silver](/wiki/Free_Silver "Free Silver") movement, which demanded using silver
to enlarge the money supply, leading to inflation that the silverites promised
would end the depression.[138]

The financial, railroad, and business communities fought back hard, arguing
that only the gold standard would save the economy. In the most intense
election in the nation's history, conservative Republican [William
McKinley](/wiki/William_McKinley "William McKinley") defeated silverite
[William Jennings Bryan](/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan "William Jennings
Bryan"), who ran on the Democratic, Populist, and Silver Republican tickets.
Bryan swept the South and West, but McKinley ran up landslides among the
middle class, industrial workers, cities, and among upscale farmers in the
Midwest.[139]

Prosperity returned under McKinley, the gold standard was enacted, and the
tariff was raised. By 1900 the U.S. had the strongest economy on the globe.
Apart from two short recessions (in 1907 and 1920) the overall economy
remained prosperous and growing until 1929. Republicans, citing McKinley's
policies, took the credit.[140]

## 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: 20th century")]

### Progressive
Era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Progressive Era")]

Main article: [Progressive Era](/wiki/Progressive_Era "Progressive Era")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg/400px-
American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg)](/wiki/File:American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:American_1902_Fourth_of_July_fireworks.jpg "Enlarge")

American children of many ethnic backgrounds celebrate noisily in a 1902
_[Puck](/wiki/Puck_\(magazine\) "Puck \(magazine\)")_ cartoon.

Dissatisfaction on the part of the growing middle class with the corruption
and inefficiency of politics as usual, and the failure to deal with
increasingly important urban and industrial problems, led to the dynamic
[Progressive Movement](/wiki/Progressive_Movement "Progressive Movement")
starting in the 1890s. In every major city and state, and at the national
level as well, and in education, medicine, and industry, the progressives
called for the modernization and reform of decrepit institutions, the
elimination of corruption in politics, and the introduction of efficiency as a
criterion for change. Leading politicians from both parties, most notably
[Theodore Roosevelt](/wiki/Theodore_Roosevelt "Theodore Roosevelt"), [Charles
Evans Hughes](/wiki/Charles_Evans_Hughes "Charles Evans Hughes"), and [Robert
La Follette](/wiki/Robert_M._La_Follette,_Sr. "Robert M. La Follette, Sr.") on
the Republican side, and [William Jennings Bryan](/wiki/William_Jennings_Bryan
"William Jennings Bryan") and [Woodrow Wilson](/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson "Woodrow
Wilson") on the Democratic side, took up the cause of progressive reform.
Women became especially involved in demands for woman suffrage, prohibition,
and better schools; their most prominent leader was [Jane
Addams](/wiki/Jane_Addams "Jane Addams") of Chicago, who created [settlement
houses](/wiki/Settlement_houses "Settlement houses"). ["Muckraking"
journalists](/wiki/Muckraker "Muckraker") such as [Upton
Sinclair](/wiki/Upton_Sinclair "Upton Sinclair"), [Lincoln
Steffens](/wiki/Lincoln_Steffens "Lincoln Steffens") and [Jacob
Riis](/wiki/Jacob_Riis "Jacob Riis") exposed corruption in business and
government along with rampant inner city poverty. Progressives implemented
anti-trust laws and regulated such industries of meat-packing, drugs, and
railroads. Four new constitutional amendments – the
[Sixteenth](/wiki/Sixteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") through
[Nineteenth](/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") – resulted from
progressive activism, bringing the federal income tax, direct election of
Senators, prohibition, and woman suffrage.[141] The Progressive Movement
lasted through the 1920s; the most active period was 1900–18.[142]

###
Imperialism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Imperialism")]

Further information: [American imperialism](/wiki/American_imperialism
"American imperialism")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Victor_Gillam_A_Thing_Well_Begun_Is_Half_Done_1899_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1136_01.jpg/220px-
Victor_Gillam_A_Thing_Well_Begun_Is_Half_Done_1899_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1136_01.jpg)](/wiki/File:Victor_Gillam_A_Thing_Well_Begun_Is_Half_Done_1899_Cornell_CUL_PJM_1136_01.jpg)

"Enlarge")

This cartoon reflects the view of [Judge magazine](/wiki/Judge_\(magazine\)
"Judge \(magazine\)") regarding America's imperial ambitions following a quick
victory in the Spanish–American War of 1898.[143] The American flag flies from
the Philippines and Hawaii in the Pacific to Cuba and Puerto Rico in the
Caribbean.

The United States emerged as a world economic and military power after 1890.
The main episode was the [Spanish–American
War](/wiki/Spanish%E2%80%93American_War "Spanish–American War"), which began
when Spain refused American demands to reform its oppressive policies in
[Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba").[144] The "splendid little war", as one official
called it, involved a series of quick American victories on land and at sea.
At the [Treaty of Paris](/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_\(1898\) "Treaty of Paris
\(1898\)") peace conference the United States acquired the
[Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), [Puerto
Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"), and [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam").[145]

Cuba became an independent country, under close American tutelage. Although
the war itself was widely popular, the peace terms proved controversial.
William Jennings Bryan led his Democratic Party in opposition to control of
the Philippines, which he denounced as
[imperialism](/wiki/American_imperialism "American imperialism") unbecoming to
American democracy.[145] President [William McKinley](/wiki/William_McKinley
"William McKinley") defended the acquisition and was riding high as the nation
had returned to prosperity and felt triumphant in the war. McKinley easily
defeated Bryan in a rematch in the [1900 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1900 "United States
presidential election, 1900").[146]

After defeating an [insurrection by Filipino
nationalists](/wiki/Philippine%E2%80%93American_War "Philippine–American
War"), the United States engaged in a large-scale program to modernize the
economy of the Philippines and dramatically upgrade the public health
facilities.[147] By 1908, however, Americans lost interest in an empire and
turned their international attention to the Caribbean, especially the building
of the [Panama Canal](/wiki/Panama_Canal "Panama Canal"). In 1912 when Arizona
became the final [mainland state](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous
United States"), the [American Frontier](/wiki/American_Frontier "American
Frontier") came to an end. The canal opened in 1914 and increased trade with
Japan and the rest of the Far East. A key innovation was the [Open Door
Policy](/wiki/Open_Door_Policy "Open Door Policy"), whereby the imperial
powers were given equal access to Chinese business, with not one of them
allowed to take control of China.[148]

and [United States home front during World War
I](/wiki/United_States_home_front_during_World_War_I "United States home front
during World War I")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Cimeti%C3%A8re_am%C3%A9ricain_de_Romagne-
sous-Montfaucon_-_1918_-_France.JPG/220px-
Cimeti%C3%A8re_am%C3%A9ricain_de_Romagne-sous-

sous-Montfaucon_-_1918_-_France.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Cimeti%C3%A8re_am%C3%A9ricain_de_Romagne-sous-
