[American Cemetery at Romagne-sous-Montfaucon](/wiki/Meuse-
Argonne_American_Cemetery_and_Memorial "Meuse-Argonne American Cemetery and
Memorial")

As [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") raged in Europe from 1914,
President Woodrow Wilson took full control of foreign policy, declaring
neutrality but warning Germany that resumption of [unrestricted submarine
warfare](/wiki/Unrestricted_submarine_warfare "Unrestricted submarine
warfare") against American ships supplying goods to Allied nations would mean
war. Germany decided to take the risk and try to win by cutting off supplies
to Britain through the sinking of ships such as the [RMS
Lusitania](/wiki/RMS_Lusitania "RMS Lusitania"); the U.S. declared war in
April 1917 mainly from the threat of the [Zimmermann
telegram](/wiki/Zimmermann_Telegram "Zimmermann Telegram").[149] American
money, food, and munitions arrived quickly, but troops had to be drafted and
trained; by summer 1918 American soldiers under General [John J.
Pershing](/wiki/John_J._Pershing "John J. Pershing") arrived at the rate of
10,000 a day, while Germany was unable to replace its losses.[150]

The result was [Allied](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I")
victory in November 1918. President Wilson demanded Germany depose the Kaiser
and accept his terms in the famed [Fourteen Points](/wiki/Fourteen_Points
"Fourteen Points") speech. Wilson dominated the [1919 Paris Peace
Conference](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919 "Paris Peace Conference, 1919")
but Germany was treated harshly by the Allies in the [Treaty of
Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") (1919) as
Wilson put all his hopes in the new [League of
Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"). Wilson refused to
compromise with Senate Republicans over the issue of Congressional power to
declare war, and the Senate rejected the Treaty and the League.[151]

### Women's
suffrage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Women's suffrage")]

Further information: [Women's suffrage in the United
States](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_the_United_States "Women's suffrage in the
United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Rose-Sanderson-Votes-
for-Women.jpeg/220px-Rose-Sanderson-Votes-for-Women.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Rose-
Sanderson-Votes-for-Women.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Rose-Sanderson-Votes-for-Women.jpeg "Enlarge")

Women suffragists demonstrating for the right to vote in 1913.

The women's suffrage movement began with the June 1848 National Convention of
the [Liberty Party](/wiki/Liberty_Party_\(1840s\) "Liberty Party \(1840s\)").
Presidential candidate [Gerrit Smith](/wiki/Gerrit_Smith "Gerrit Smith")
argued for and established women's suffrage as a party plank. One month later,
his cousin [Elizabeth Cady Stanton](/wiki/Elizabeth_Cady_Stanton "Elizabeth
Cady Stanton") joined with [Lucretia Mott](/wiki/Lucretia_Mott "Lucretia
Mott") and other women to organize the [Seneca Falls
Convention](/wiki/Seneca_Falls_Convention "Seneca Falls Convention"),
featuring the [Declaration of Sentiments](/wiki/Declaration_of_Sentiments
"Declaration of Sentiments") demanding equal rights for women, and the right
to vote.[152] Many of these activists became politically aware during the
abolitionist movement. The women's rights campaign during "[first-wave
feminism](/wiki/First-wave_feminism "First-wave feminism")" was led by
Stanton, [Lucy Stone](/wiki/Lucy_Stone "Lucy Stone") and [Susan B.
Anthony](/wiki/Susan_B._Anthony "Susan B. Anthony"), among many others. Stone
and [Paulina Wright Davis](/wiki/Paulina_Wright_Davis "Paulina Wright Davis")
organized the prominent and influential [National Women's Rights
Convention](/wiki/National_Women%27s_Rights_Convention "National Women's
Rights Convention") in 1850. The movement reorganized after the Civil War,
gaining experienced campaigners, many of whom had worked for prohibition in
the [Women's Christian Temperance
Union](/wiki/Women%27s_Christian_Temperance_Union "Women's Christian
Temperance Union"). By the end of the 19th century a few western states had
granted women full voting rights,[153] though women had made significant legal
victories, gaining rights in areas such as property and child custody.[154]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Suffragists_Parade_Down_Fifth_Avenue%2C_1917.JPG/260px-
Suffragists_Parade_Down_Fifth_Avenue%2C_1917.JPG)](/wiki/File:Suffragists_Parade_Down_Fifth_Avenue,_1917.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Suffragists_Parade_Down_Fifth_Avenue,_1917.JPG "Enlarge")

Women's suffragists parade in New York City in 1917, carrying placards with
signatures of more than a million women.[155]

Around 1912 the [feminist movement](/wiki/Feminist_movement "Feminist
movement") began to reawaken, putting an emphasis on its demands for equality
and arguing that the corruption of American politics demanded purification by
women because men could not do that job.[156] Protests became increasingly
common as suffragette [Alice Paul](/wiki/Alice_Paul "Alice Paul") led parades
through the capital and major cities. Paul split from the large [National
American Woman Suffrage
Association](/wiki/National_American_Woman_Suffrage_Association "National
American Woman Suffrage Association") (NAWSA), which favored a more moderate
approach and supported the Democratic Party and Woodrow Wilson, led by [Carrie
Chapman Catt](/wiki/Carrie_Chapman_Catt "Carrie Chapman Catt"), and formed the
more militant [National Woman's Party](/wiki/National_Woman%27s_Party
"National Woman's Party"). Suffragists were arrested during their "[Silent
Sentinels](/wiki/Silent_Sentinels "Silent Sentinels")" pickets at the White
House, the first time such a tactic was used, and were taken as [political
prisoners](/wiki/Political_prisoner "Political prisoner").[157]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Women_voter_outreach_1935_English_Yiddish.jpg/220px-
Women_voter_outreach_1935_English_Yiddish.jpg)](/wiki/File:Women_voter_outreach_1935_English_Yiddish.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Women_voter_outreach_1935_English_Yiddish.jpg "Enlarge")

Women surrounded by posters in English and [Yiddish](/wiki/Yiddish "Yiddish")
supporting [Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D.
Roosevelt"), [Herbert H. Lehman](/wiki/Herbert_H._Lehman "Herbert H. Lehman"),
and the [American Labor Party](/wiki/American_Labor_Party "American Labor
Party") teach other women how to vote, 1936.

The old anti-suffragist argument that only men could fight a war, and
therefore only men deserve the right to vote, was refuted by the enthusiastic
participation of tens of thousands of American women on the home front in
World War I. Across the world, grateful nations gave women the right to vote.
Furthermore, most of the Western states had already given the women the right
to vote in state and national elections, and the representatives from those
states, including the first woman [Jeannette Rankin](/wiki/Jeannette_Rankin
"Jeannette Rankin") of Montana, demonstrated that woman suffrage was a
success. The main resistance came from the south, where white leaders were
worried about the threat of black women voting. Congress passed the
[Nineteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Nineteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution") in 1919, and women
could vote in 1920.[158]

NAWSA became the [League of Women Voters](/wiki/League_of_Women_Voters "League
of Women Voters"), and the National Woman's Party began lobbying for full
equality and the [Equal Rights Amendment](/wiki/Equal_Rights_Amendment "Equal
Rights Amendment"), which would pass Congress during the second wave of the
women's movement in 1972. Politicians responded to the new electorate by
emphasizing issues of special interest to women, especially prohibition, child
health, and world peace.[159][160] The main surge of women voting came in
1928, when the big-city machines realized they needed the support of women to
elect [Al Smith](/wiki/Al_Smith "Al Smith"), a Catholic from New York City.
Meanwhile, Protestants mobilized women to support Prohibition and vote for
Republican [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert Hoover").[161]

### Roaring Twenties and the Great
Depression[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Roaring Twenties and the Great Depression")]

Main article: [History of the United States
(1918–45)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1918%E2%80%9345\) "History of
the United States \(1918–45\)")

Further information: [Great Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great
Depression"), [Causes of the Great
Depression](/wiki/Causes_of_the_Great_Depression "Causes of the Great
Depression"), and [New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Prohibition_agents_destroying_barrels_of_alcohol_%28United_States%2C_prohibition_era%29.jpg/220px-
Prohibition_agents_destroying_barrels_of_alcohol_%28United_States%2C_prohibition_era%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Prohibition_agents_destroying_barrels_of_alcohol_\(United_States,_prohibition_era\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Prohibition_agents_destroying_barrels_of_alcohol_\(United_States,_prohibition_era\).jpg
"Enlarge")

[Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition in the
United States") agents destroying barrels of alcohol in Chicago, 1921.

In the 1920s the U.S. grew steadily in stature as an economic and military
world power. The United States Senate did not ratify the [Treaty of
Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") imposed by its
[Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I "Allies of World War I") on the defeated
[Central Powers](/wiki/Central_Powers "Central Powers"); instead, the United
States chose to pursue [unilateralism](/wiki/Unilateralism
"Unilateralism").[162] The aftershock of Russia's [October
Revolution](/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") resulted in real
fears of Communism in the United States, leading to a [Red
Scare](/wiki/First_Red_Scare "First Red Scare") and the deportation of aliens
considered subversive.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Money_supply_during_the_great_depression_era.png/400px-
Money_supply_during_the_great_depression_era.png)](/wiki/File:Money_supply_during_the_great_depression_era.png)

[](/wiki/File:Money_supply_during_the_great_depression_era.png "Enlarge")

Money supply decreased a lot between [Black Tuesday](/wiki/Black_Tuesday
"Black Tuesday") and the [Bank Holiday in March
1933](/wiki/Emergency_Banking_Act "Emergency Banking Act") when there were
massive [bank runs](/wiki/Bank_runs "Bank runs") across the United States.

While public health facilities grew rapidly in the Progressive Era, and
hospitals and medical schools were modernized,[163] the nation in 1918 lost
675,000 lives to the [Spanish flu](/wiki/Spanish_flu "Spanish flu")
pandemic.[164]

In 1920, the manufacture, sale, import and export of alcohol were prohibited
by the [Eighteenth
Amendment](/wiki/Eighteenth_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution
"Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution"),
[Prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition_in_the_United_States "Prohibition in the
United States"). The result was that in cities illegal alcohol became a big
business, largely controlled by racketeers. The second [Ku Klux
Klan](/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan "Ku Klux Klan") grew rapidly in 1922–25, then
collapsed. Immigration laws were passed to strictly limit the number of new
entries. The 1920s were called the [Roaring Twenties](/wiki/Roaring_Twenties
"Roaring Twenties") due to the great economic prosperity during this period.
[Jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") became popular among the younger generation, and
thus the decade was also called the [Jazz Age](/wiki/Jazz_Age "Jazz Age").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Lange-
MigrantMother02.jpg/220px-Lange-MigrantMother02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lange-
MigrantMother02.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lange-MigrantMother02.jpg "Enlarge")

[Dorothea Lange](/wiki/Dorothea_Lange "Dorothea Lange")'s _Migrant Mother_
depicts destitute pea pickers in California, centering on [Florence Owens
Thompson](/wiki/Florence_Owens_Thompson "Florence Owens Thompson"), a mother
of seven, age 32, in [Nipomo, California](/wiki/Nipomo,_California "Nipomo,
California"), March 1936.

The Great Depression (1929–39) and the New Deal (1933–36) were decisive
moments in American political, economic, and social history that reshaped the
nation.[165]

During the 1920s, the nation enjoyed widespread prosperity, albeit with a
weakness in agriculture. A financial bubble was fueled by an inflated [stock
market](/wiki/Stock_market "Stock market"), which later led to the [Stock
Market Crash](/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929 "Wall Street Crash of 1929") on
October 29, 1929.[166] This, along with [many other economic
factors](/wiki/Causes_of_the_Great_Depression "Causes of the Great
Depression"), triggered a worldwide [depression](/wiki/Economic_depression
"Economic depression") known as the [Great Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression
"Great Depression"). During this time, the United States experienced
[deflation](/wiki/Deflation_\(economics\) "Deflation \(economics\)") as prices
fell, unemployment soared from 3% in 1929 to 25% in 1933, farm prices fell by
half, and manufacturing output plunged by one-third.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/FDR_Inauguration_1933.jpg/250px-
FDR_Inauguration_1933.jpg)](/wiki/File:FDR_Inauguration_1933.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FDR_Inauguration_1933.jpg "Enlarge")

Outgoing president [Herbert Hoover](/wiki/Herbert_Hoover "Herbert Hoover") and
[Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt") on
[Inauguration Day](/wiki/Inauguration_Day "Inauguration Day"), 1933

In 1932, [Democratic](/wiki/History_of_the_Democratic_Party_\(United_States\)
"History of the Democratic Party \(United States\)") presidential nominee
[Franklin D. Roosevelt](/wiki/Franklin_D._Roosevelt "Franklin D. Roosevelt")
promised "a [New Deal](/wiki/New_Deal "New Deal") for the American people",
coining the enduring label for his domestic policies. The desperate economic
situation, along with the substantial Democratic victories in the 1932
elections, gave Roosevelt unusual influence over Congress in the "First
Hundred Days" of his administration. He used his leverage to win rapid passage
of a series of measures to create welfare programs and regulate the banking
system, stock market, industry, and agriculture, along with many other
government efforts to end the Great Depression and reform the American
economy. The New Deal regulated much of the economy, especially the financial
sector. It provided relief to the unemployed through numerous programs, such
as the [Works Progress Administration](/wiki/Works_Progress_Administration
"Works Progress Administration") (WPA) and for young men, the [Civilian
Conservation Corps](/wiki/Civilian_Conservation_Corps "Civilian Conservation
Corps") that undertook jobs such as forest fire fighting and creating public
works. Large scale spending projects designed to provide high paying jobs and
rebuild the infrastructure were under the purview of the [Public Works
Administration](/wiki/Public_Works_Administration "Public Works
Administration"). Roosevelt turned left in 1935–36, building up labor unions
through the [Wagner Act](/wiki/Wagner_Act "Wagner Act"). Unions became a
powerful element of the merging [New Deal Coalition](/wiki/New_Deal_Coalition
"New Deal Coalition"), which won reelection for Roosevelt in 1936, 1940, and
1944 by mobilizing union members, blue collar workers, relief recipients, big
city machines, ethnic, and religious groups (especially Catholics and Jews)
and the white South, along with blacks in the North (where they could vote).
Some of the programs were dropped in the 1940s when the conservatives regained
power in Congress through the [Conservative
Coalition](/wiki/Conservative_Coalition "Conservative Coalition"). Of special
importance is the [Social Security
program](/wiki/Social_Security_\(United_States\) "Social Security \(United
States\)"), begun in 1935.[167]

### World War
II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: World War II")]

Further information: [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"),
[Military history of the United States during World War
II](/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_States_during_World_War_II "Military
history of the United States during World War II"), and [United States home
front during World War II](/wiki/United_States_home_front_during_World_War_II
"United States home front during World War II")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/The_USS_Arizona_%28BB-39%29_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg/220px-
The_USS_Arizona_%28BB-39%29_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:The_USS_Arizona_\(BB-39\)_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:The_USS_Arizona_\(BB-39\)_burning_after_the_Japanese_attack_on_Pearl_Harbor_-
_NARA_195617_-_Edit.jpg "Enlarge")

The Japanese crippled American naval power with the [attack on Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor"), destroying
many battleships.

In the Depression years, the United States remained focused on domestic
concerns while democracy declined across the world and many countries fell
under the control of dictators. [Imperial Japan](/wiki/Empire_of_Japan "Empire
of Japan") asserted dominance in East Asia and in the Pacific. [Nazi
Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") and [Fascist
Italy](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy_\(1861%E2%80%931946\) "Kingdom of Italy
\(1861–1946\)") militarized and threatened conquests, while Britain and France
attempted [appeasement](/wiki/Appeasement "Appeasement") to avert another war
in Europe. U.S. legislation in the [Neutrality
Acts](/wiki/Neutrality_Acts_of_1930s "Neutrality Acts of 1930s") sought to
avoid foreign conflicts; however, policy clashed with increasing anti-Nazi
feelings following the German [invasion of Poland](/wiki/Invasion_of_Poland
"Invasion of Poland") in September 1939 that started World War II. Roosevelt
positioned the U.S. as the "[Arsenal of Democracy](/wiki/Arsenal_of_Democracy
"Arsenal of Democracy")", pledging full-scale financial and munitions support
for the Allies – but no military personnel.[168] This was carried out through
the [Lend-Lease](/wiki/Lend-Lease "Lend-Lease") agreements. Japan tried to
neutralize America's power in the Pacific by [attacking Pearl
Harbor](/wiki/Attack_on_Pearl_Harbor "Attack on Pearl Harbor") on December 7,
1941, which catalyzed American support to enter the war.[169]

The main contributions of the U.S. to the Allied war effort comprised money,
industrial output, food, petroleum, technological innovation, and (especially
1944–45), military personnel. Much of the focus in Washington was maximizing
the economic output of the nation. The overall result was a dramatic increase
in GDP, the export of vast quantities of supplies to the Allies and to
American forces overseas, the end of unemployment, and a rise in civilian
consumption even as 40% of the GDP went to the war effort. This was achieved
by tens of millions of workers moving from low-productivity occupations to
high efficiency jobs, improvements in productivity through better technology
and management, and the move into the active labor force of students, retired
people, housewives, and the unemployed, and an increase in hours worked.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg/220px-
Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg)](/wiki/File:Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Into_the_Jaws_of_Death_23-0455M_edit.jpg "Enlarge")

_[Into the Jaws of Death](/wiki/Into_the_Jaws_of_Death "Into the Jaws of
Death")_ : The [Normandy landings](/wiki/Normandy_landings "Normandy
landings") began the Allied march toward Germany from the west.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Tarawa_beach_HD-
SN-99-03001.JPEG/220px-Tarawa_beach_HD-
SN-99-03001.JPEG)](/wiki/File:Tarawa_beach_HD-SN-99-03001.JPEG)

[](/wiki/File:Tarawa_beach_HD-SN-99-03001.JPEG "Enlarge")

American corpses sprawled on the beach of [Tarawa](/wiki/Battle_of_Tarawa
"Battle of Tarawa"), November 1943.

It was exhausting; leisure activities declined sharply. People tolerated the
extra work because of patriotism, the pay, and the confidence that it was only
"for the duration", and life would return to normal as soon as the war was
won. Most durable goods became unavailable, and meat, clothing, and gasoline
were tightly rationed. In industrial areas housing was in short supply as
people doubled up and lived in cramped quarters. Prices and wages were
controlled, and Americans saved a high portion of their incomes, which led to
renewed growth after the war instead of a return to depression.[170][171]

The [Allies](/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II "Allies of World War II") – the
United States, Britain, and the Soviet Union, China, as well as Poland, Canada
and other countries – fought the [Axis powers](/wiki/Axis_powers "Axis
powers") of Germany, Italy, and Japan. The Allies saw Germany as the main
threat and gave highest priority to Europe. The U.S. dominated the war against
Japan and stopped Japanese expansion in the Pacific in 1942. After losing
Pearl Harbor and in the Philippines to the Japanese, and drawing the [Battle
of the Coral Sea](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Coral_Sea "Battle of the Coral Sea")
(May 1942), the American Navy inflicted a decisive blow at
[Midway](/wiki/Battle_of_Midway "Battle of Midway") (June 1942). American
ground forces assisted in the [North African
Campaign](/wiki/North_African_Campaign "North African Campaign") that
eventually concluded with the collapse of Mussolini's fascist government in
1943, as Italy switched to the Allied side. A more significant European front
was opened on [D-Day](/wiki/D-Day "D-Day"), June 6, 1944, in which American
and Allied forces invaded Nazi-occupied France from Britain.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Eisenhower_bronze.jpg/150px-
Eisenhower_bronze.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eisenhower_bronze.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eisenhower_bronze.jpg "Enlarge")

Bronze statue of [Eisenhower](/wiki/Eisenhower "Eisenhower") at [Capitol
rotunda](/wiki/United_States_Capitol_rotunda "United States Capitol
rotunda").[172]

On the [home front](/wiki/United_States_home_front_during_World_War_II "United
States home front during World War II"), mobilization of the U.S. economy was
managed by Roosevelt's [War Production Board](/wiki/War_Production_Board "War
Production Board"). The wartime production boom led to full employment, wiping
out this vestige of the Great Depression. Indeed, [labor
shortages](/wiki/Labor_shortage "Labor shortage") encouraged industry to look
for new sources of workers, finding new roles for women and blacks.[173]

However, the fervor also inspired [anti-Japanese sentiment](/wiki/Anti-
Japanese_sentiment_in_the_United_States "Anti-Japanese sentiment in the United
States"), leading to [internment](/wiki/Internment_of_Japanese_Americans
"Internment of Japanese Americans") of Japanese-Americans.[174]

[Research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and
development") took flight as well, best seen in the [Manhattan
Project](/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project"), a secret effort to
harness [nuclear fission](/wiki/Nuclear_fission "Nuclear fission") to produce
highly destructive [atomic bombs](/wiki/Atomic_bomb "Atomic bomb").[175]

The Allies pushed the Germans out of France but faced an unexpected
counterattack at the [Battle of the Bulge](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bulge "Battle
of the Bulge") in December. The final German effort failed, and, as Allied
armies in East and West were converging on Berlin, the Nazis hurriedly tried
to kill the last remaining Jews. The western front stopped short, leaving
Berlin to the Soviets as the Nazi regime formally capitulated in May 1945,
ending the war in Europe.[176] Over in the Pacific, the U.S. implemented an
[island hopping strategy](/wiki/Leapfrogging_\(strategy\) "Leapfrogging
\(strategy\)") toward Tokyo, establishing airfields for bombing runs against
mainland Japan from the [Mariana Islands](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana
Islands") and achieving hard-fought victories at [Iwo
Jima](/wiki/Battle_of_Iwo_Jima "Battle of Iwo Jima") and
[Okinawa](/wiki/Battle_of_Okinawa "Battle of Okinawa") in 1945.[177] Bloodied
at Okinawa, the U.S. prepared to [invade Japan's home
islands](/wiki/Operation_Downfall "Operation Downfall") when
[B-29s](/wiki/B-29 "B-29") [dropped atomic
bombs](/wiki/Atomic_bombings_of_Hiroshima_and_Nagasaki "Atomic bombings of
Hiroshima and Nagasaki") on the Japanese cities of [Hiroshima](/wiki/Hiroshima
"Hiroshima") and [Nagasaki](/wiki/Nagasaki "Nagasaki"), forcing the empire's
surrender in a matter of days and thus ending World War II.[178] The U.S.
occupied Japan (and part of Germany), sending [Douglas
MacArthur](/wiki/Douglas_MacArthur "Douglas MacArthur") to restructure the
Japanese economy and political system along American lines.[179] During the
war, Roosevelt coined the term "[Four Powers](/wiki/Four_Policemen "Four
Policemen")" to refer four major Allies of World War II, the United States,
the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union and China, which later became the
foundation of the United Nations Security Council.[180]

Though the nation lost more than 400,000 military personnel,[181] the mainland
prospered untouched by the devastation of war that inflicted a heavy toll on
Europe and Asia.

Participation in postwar foreign affairs marked the end of predominant
American isolationism. The awesome threat of nuclear weapons inspired both
[optimism](/wiki/Nuclear_power_debate "Nuclear power debate") and
[fear](/wiki/Mutual_assured_destruction "Mutual assured destruction"). Nuclear
weapons were never used after 1945, as both sides drew back from the brink and
a "long peace" characterized the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War") years,
starting with the [Truman](/wiki/Harry_Truman "Harry Truman")
[Doctrine](/wiki/Truman_Doctrine "Truman Doctrine") in May 22, 1947. There
were, however, regional wars in [Korea](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") and
[Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War").[182]

### The Cold War, counterculture, and civil
rights[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: The Cold War, counterculture, and civil rights")]

Main articles: [History of the United States
(1945–64)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1945%E2%80%9364\) "History of
the United States \(1945–64\)"), [History of the United States
(1964–80)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1964%E2%80%9380\) "History of
the United States \(1964–80\)"), and [United States in the
1950s](/wiki/United_States_in_the_1950s "United States in the 1950s")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg/250px-
John_Kennedy%2C_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg)](/wiki/File:John_Kennedy,_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:John_Kennedy,_Nikita_Khrushchev_1961.jpg "Enlarge")

Cuban Missile Crisis a meeting with Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev in
[Vienna](/wiki/Vienna "Vienna") in 1961.

Following World War II, the United States emerged as one of the two dominant
superpowers, the [USSR](/wiki/USSR "USSR") being the other. The [U.S.
Senate](/wiki/U.S._Senate "U.S. Senate") on a bipartisan vote approved U.S.
participation in the United Nations (UN), which marked a turn away from the
traditional [isolationism](/wiki/Isolationism "Isolationism") of the U.S. and
toward increased international involvement.

The primary American goal of 1945–48 was to rescue Europe from the devastation
of World War II and to contain the expansion of Communism, represented by the
[Soviet Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union"). [U.S. foreign
policy](/wiki/Foreign_policy_of_the_United_States "Foreign policy of the
United States") during the Cold War was built around the support of [Western
Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe") and [Japan](/wiki/Japan
"Japan") along with the policy of [containment](/wiki/Containment
"Containment"), stopping the spread of [communism](/wiki/Communism
"Communism"). The U.S. joined the wars in [Korea](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean
War") and [Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") to try to stop its
spread. The [Truman Doctrine](/wiki/Truman_Doctrine "Truman Doctrine") of 1947
provided military and economic aid to Greece and Turkey to counteract the
threat of Communist expansion in the Balkans. In 1948, the United States
replaced piecemeal financial aid programs with a comprehensive [Marshall
Plan](/wiki/Marshall_Plan "Marshall Plan"), which pumped money into the
economy of Western Europe, and removed trade barriers, while modernizing the
managerial practices of businesses and governments.[183]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg/220px-
President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights%2C_11_June_1963.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights,_11_June_1963.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:President_Kennedy_addresses_nation_on_Civil_Rights,_11_June_1963.jpg
"Enlarge")

[President Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy")'s [Civil Rights
Address](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Address "Civil Rights Address"), June 11, 1963.

The Plan's $13 billion budget was in the context of a U.S. GDP of $258 billion
in 1948 and was in addition to the $12 billion in American aid given to Europe
between the end of the war and the start of the Marshall Plan. Soviet head of
state [Joseph Stalin](/wiki/Joseph_Stalin "Joseph Stalin") prevented [his
satellite states](/wiki/Eastern_Bloc "Eastern Bloc") from participating, and
from that point on, Eastern Europe, with inefficient centralized economies,
fell further and further behind Western Europe in terms of economic
development and prosperity. In 1949, the United States, rejecting the long-
standing policy of no military alliances in peacetime, formed the [North
Atlantic Treaty Organization](/wiki/North_Atlantic_Treaty_Organization "North
Atlantic Treaty Organization") (NATO) alliance, which continues into the 21st
century. In response the Soviets formed the [Warsaw Pact](/wiki/Warsaw_Pact
"Warsaw Pact") of communist states, leading to the "[iron
curtain](/wiki/Iron_Curtain "Iron Curtain")".[183]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Aldrin_Apollo_11_original.jpg/250px-
Aldrin_Apollo_11_original.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aldrin_Apollo_11_original.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aldrin_Apollo_11_original.jpg "Enlarge")

[Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11")

In August 1949 the Soviets tested their first nuclear weapon, thereby
escalating the risk of warfare. The threat of [mutually assured
destruction](/wiki/Mutually_assured_destruction "Mutually assured
destruction") however, prevented both powers from nuclear war, and resulted in
proxy wars, especially in [Korea](/wiki/Korean_War "Korean War") and
[Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War"), in which the two sides did not
directly confront each other.[182] Within the United States, the Cold War
prompted concerns about [Communist influence](/wiki/Second_Red_Scare "Second
Red Scare"). The unexpected leapfrogging of American technology by the Soviets
in 1957 with [Sputnik](/wiki/Sputnik "Sputnik"), the first Earth satellite,
began the [Space Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), won by the Americans as
[Apollo 11](/wiki/Apollo_11 "Apollo 11") landed astronauts on the moon in
1969. The angst about the weaknesses of American education led to large-scale
federal support for [science education](/wiki/Science_education#United_States
"Science education") and research.[184]

In the decades after World War II, the United States became a global influence
in economic, political, military, cultural, and technological affairs.
Beginning in the 1950s, middle-class culture became obsessed with consumer
goods. [White Americans](/wiki/White_Americans "White Americans") made up
nearly 90% of the population in 1950.[185][_[clarification
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify "Wikipedia:Please clarify")_]

In [1960](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1960 "United States
presidential election, 1960"), the charismatic politician [John F.
Kennedy](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy") was elected as the first and
– thus far – only Roman Catholic President of the United States. The Kennedy
family brought a new life and vigor to the atmosphere of the [White
House](/wiki/White_House "White House"). His time in office was marked by such
notable events as the acceleration of the United States' role in the [Space
Race](/wiki/Space_Race "Space Race"), escalation of the American role in the
[Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War"), the [Cuban missile
crisis](/wiki/Cuban_missile_crisis "Cuban missile crisis"), the [Bay of Pigs
Invasion](/wiki/Bay_of_Pigs_Invasion "Bay of Pigs Invasion"), the jailing of
[Martin Luther King, Jr.](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King,_Jr. "Martin Luther King,
Jr.") during the [Birmingham campaign](/wiki/Birmingham_campaign "Birmingham
campaign"), and the appointment of his brother [Robert F.
Kennedy](/wiki/Robert_F._Kennedy "Robert F. Kennedy") to his Cabinet as
[Attorney General](/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General "United States
Attorney General"). [Kennedy was
assassinated](/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_assassination "John F. Kennedy
assassination") in [Dallas](/wiki/Dallas "Dallas"), Texas, on November 22,
1963, leaving the nation in profound shock.[186]

#### Climax of
liberalism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=37
"Edit section: Climax of liberalism")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/12th_Inf%2C_4th_Inf_Div%2C_Vietnam_War_Hill_530.jpg/190px-12th_Inf%2C_4th_Inf_Div%2C_Vietnam_War_Hill_530.jpg)](/wiki/File:12th_Inf,_4th_Inf_Div,_Vietnam_War_Hill_530.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:12th_Inf,_4th_Inf_Div,_Vietnam_War_Hill_530.jpg "Enlarge")

American soldiers during the Vietnam War, 1967

The climax of [liberalism](/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States
"Modern liberalism in the United States") came in the mid-1960s with the
success of President [Lyndon B. Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B.
Johnson") (1963–69) in securing congressional passage of his [Great
Society](/wiki/Great_Society "Great Society") programs.[187] They included
civil rights, the end of
[segregation](/wiki/Racial_segregation_in_the_United_States "Racial
segregation in the United States"),
[Medicare](/wiki/Medicare_\(United_States\) "Medicare \(United States\)"),
extension of welfare, federal aid to education at all levels, subsidies for
the arts and humanities, environmental activism, and a series of programs
designed to wipe out poverty.[188][189] As recent historians have explained:

> Gradually, liberal intellectuals crafted a new vision for achieving economic
> and social justice. The liberalism of the early 1960s contained no hint of
> radicalism, little disposition to revive new deal era crusades against
> concentrated economic power, and no intention to redistribute wealth or
> restructure existing institutions. Internationally it was strongly anti-
> Communist. It aimed to defend the free world, to encourage economic growth
> at home, and to ensure that the resulting plenty was fairly distributed.
> Their agenda-much influenced by Keynesian economic theory-envisioned massive
> public expenditure that would speed economic growth, thus providing the
> public resources to fund larger welfare, housing, health, and educational
> programs.[190]

Johnson was rewarded with an [electoral landslide in
1964](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1964 "United States
presidential election, 1964") against conservative [Barry
Goldwater](/wiki/Barry_Goldwater "Barry Goldwater"), which broke the decades-
long control of Congress by the [Conservative
coalition](/wiki/Conservative_coalition "Conservative coalition"). However,
the Republicans bounced back in 1966 and elected [Richard
Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon") in 1968. Nixon largely continued
the New Deal and Great Society programs he inherited; conservative reaction
would come with the election of [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald
Reagan") in 1980.[191] Meanwhile, the American people completed a great
migration from farms into the cities and experienced a period of sustained
economic expansion.

#### Civil Rights
Movement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: Civil Rights Movement")]

Main article: [Civil Rights Movement](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Movement "Civil
Rights Movement")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Martin_Luther_King%2C_Jr._and_Lyndon_Johnson.jpg/175px-
Martin_Luther_King%2C_Jr._and_Lyndon_Johnson.jpg)](/wiki/File:Martin_Luther_King,_Jr._and_Lyndon_Johnson.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Martin_Luther_King,_Jr._and_Lyndon_Johnson.jpg "Enlarge")

Civil Rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. (right), with President Lyndon B.
Johnson in the background (left)

Starting in the late 1950s, institutionalized [racism across the United
States](/wiki/Racism_in_the_United_States "Racism in the United States"), but
especially in the [South](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United
States"), was increasingly challenged by the growing Civil Rights Movement.
The activism of African-American leaders [Rosa Parks](/wiki/Rosa_Parks "Rosa
Parks") and [Martin Luther King, Jr.](/wiki/Martin_Luther_King,_Jr. "Martin
Luther King, Jr.") led to the [Montgomery Bus
Boycott](/wiki/Montgomery_Bus_Boycott "Montgomery Bus Boycott"), which
launched the movement. For years African Americans would struggle with
violence against them but would achieve great steps toward equality with
Supreme Court decisions, including _[Brown v. Board of
Education](/wiki/Brown_v._Board_of_Education "Brown v. Board of Education")_
and _[Loving v. Virginia](/wiki/Loving_v._Virginia "Loving v. Virginia")_ ,
the [Civil Rights Act of 1964](/wiki/Civil_Rights_Act_of_1964 "Civil Rights
Act of 1964"), the [Voting Rights Act of 1965](/wiki/Voting_Rights_Act_of_1965
"Voting Rights Act of 1965"), and the [Fair Housing Act of
1968](/wiki/Fair_Housing_Act_of_1968 "Fair Housing Act of 1968"), which ended
the [Jim Crow laws](/wiki/Jim_Crow_laws "Jim Crow laws") that legalized
[racial segregation](/wiki/Racial_segregation "Racial segregation") between
whites and blacks.[192]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Cesar_chavez2.jpg/200px-
Cesar_chavez2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cesar_chavez2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cesar_chavez2.jpg "Enlarge")

Duncan West speaking with [Cesar Chavez](/wiki/Cesar_Chavez "Cesar Chavez").
The Delano [UFW](/wiki/UFW "UFW") rally. Duncan represented the
[Teamsters](/wiki/Teamsters "Teamsters") who were supporting the UFW and
condemning their IBT leadership for working as thugs against a fellow union.
Duncan and his wife Mary were the branch organizers of the LA IS.

Martin Luther King, Jr., who had won the [Nobel Peace
Prize](/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize "Nobel Peace Prize") for his efforts to achieve
equality of the races, was [assassinated in
1968](/wiki/Assassination_of_Martin_Luther_King,_Jr. "Assassination of Martin
Luther King, Jr."). Following his death others led the movement, most notably
King's widow, [Coretta Scott King](/wiki/Coretta_Scott_King "Coretta Scott
King"), who was also active, like her husband, in the [Opposition to the
Vietnam War](/wiki/Opposition_to_the_Vietnam_War "Opposition to the Vietnam
War"), and in the [Women's Liberation
Movement](/wiki/Feminist_Movement_in_the_United_States "Feminist Movement in
the United States"). There were 164 riots in 128 American cities in the first
nine months of 1967.[193] Frustrations with the seemingly slow progress of the
integration movement led to the emergence of more radical discourses during
the early 1960s, which, in turn, gave rise to the [Black
Power](/wiki/Black_Power "Black Power") movement of the late 1960s and early
1970s.[194] The decade would ultimately bring about positive strides toward
integration, especially in government service, sports, and entertainment.
[Native Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States "Native
Americans in the United States") turned to the federal courts to fight for
their land rights. They held protests highlighting the federal government's
failure to honor treaties. One of the most outspoken Native American groups
was the [American Indian Movement](/wiki/American_Indian_Movement "American
Indian Movement") (AIM). In the 1960s, [Cesar Chavez](/wiki/Cesar_Chavez
"Cesar Chavez") began organizing poorly paid [Mexican-American](/wiki/Mexican-
American "Mexican-American") farm workers in California. He led a five-year-
long strike by grape pickers. Then Chávez formed the nation's first successful
union of farm workers. His [United Farm Workers of
America](/wiki/United_Farm_Workers_of_America "United Farm Workers of
America") (UFW) faltered after a few years but after Chavez died in 1993 he
became an iconic "folk saint" in the pantheon of Mexican Americans.[195]

#### The Women's
Movement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: The Women's Movement")]

Further information: [Second-wave feminism](/wiki/Second-wave_feminism
"Second-wave feminism")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Vietnamdem.jpg/250px-
Vietnamdem.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vietnamdem.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vietnamdem.jpg "Enlarge")

Anti-Vietnam War demonstration, 1967

A new consciousness of the inequality of American women began sweeping the
nation, starting with the 1963 publication of [Betty
Friedan](/wiki/Betty_Friedan "Betty Friedan")'s best-seller, _[The Feminine
Mystique](/wiki/The_Feminine_Mystique "The Feminine Mystique")_ , which
explained how many [housewives](/wiki/Homemakers "Homemakers") felt trapped
and unfulfilled, assaulted American culture for its creation of the notion
that women could only find fulfillment through their roles as wives, mothers,
and keepers of the home, and argued that women were just as able as men to do
every type of job. In 1966 Friedan and others established the [National
Organization for Women](/wiki/National_Organization_for_Women "National
Organization for Women"), or NOW, to act for women as the [NAACP](/wiki/NAACP
"NAACP") did for African Americans.[154][196]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Woodstock_redmond_hair.JPG/250px-
Woodstock_redmond_hair.JPG)](/wiki/File:Woodstock_redmond_hair.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Woodstock_redmond_hair.JPG "Enlarge")

Two [hippies](/wiki/Hippies "Hippies") at [Woodstock](/wiki/Woodstock
"Woodstock")

Protests began, and the new Women's Liberation Movement grew in size and
power, gained much media attention, and, by 1968, had replaced the Civil
Rights Movement as the U.S's main social revolution. Marches, parades,
rallies, boycotts, and pickets brought out thousands, sometimes millions.
There were striking gains for women in medicine, law, and business, while only
a few were elected to office. The Movement was split into factions by
political ideology early on, however (with NOW on the left, the [Women's
Equity Action League](/wiki/Women%27s_Equity_Action_League "Women's Equity
Action League") (WEAL) on the right, the [National Women's Political
Caucus](/wiki/National_Women%27s_Political_Caucus "National Women's Political
Caucus") (NWPC) in the center, and more radical groups formed by younger women
on the far left). The proposed [Equal Rights
Amendment](/wiki/Equal_Rights_Amendment "Equal Rights Amendment") to the
Constitution, passed by Congress in 1972 was defeated by a conservative
coalition mobilized by [Phyllis Schlafly](/wiki/Phyllis_Schlafly "Phyllis
Schlafly"). They argued that it degraded the position of the housewife and
made young women susceptible to the [military
draft](/wiki/Conscription_in_the_United_States "Conscription in the United
States").[197][198]

However, many federal laws (i.e., those [equalizing
pay](/wiki/Equal_Pay_Act_of_1963 "Equal Pay Act of 1963"),
[employment](/wiki/Title_VII "Title VII"), [education](/wiki/Title_IX "Title
IX"), [employment opportunities](/wiki/Equal_Employment_Opportunity_Act "Equal
Employment Opportunity Act"), and [credit](/wiki/Equal_Credit_Opportunity_Act
"Equal Credit Opportunity Act"); [ending pregnancy
discrimination](/wiki/Pregnancy_Discrimination_Act "Pregnancy Discrimination
Act"); and requiring [NASA](/wiki/NASA "NASA"), the [Military
Academies](/wiki/Military_Academies "Military Academies"), and other
organizations to admit women), state laws (i.e., those ending [spousal
abuse](/wiki/Spousal_abuse "Spousal abuse") and [marital
rape](/wiki/Spousal_rape "Spousal rape")), Supreme Court rulings (i.e. ruling
that the equal protection clause of the Fourteenth Amendment applied to
women), and state ERAs established women's equal status under the law, and
social custom and consciousness began to change, accepting women's equality.
The controversial issue of abortion, deemed by the Supreme Court as a
[fundamental right](/wiki/Fundamental_right "Fundamental right") in _[Roe v.
Wade](/wiki/Roe_v._Wade "Roe v. Wade")_ (1973), is still a [point of
debate](/wiki/Abortion_debate "Abortion debate") today.[199]

#### The Counterculture Revolution and Cold War
Détente[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=40
"Edit section: The Counterculture Revolution and Cold War Détente")]

Main article: [History of the United States
(1964–80)](/wiki/History_of_the_United_States_\(1964%E2%80%9380\) "History of
the United States \(1964–80\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/F-4B_VF-151_CV-41_TU-95.jpg/220px-F-4B_VF-151_CV-41_TU-95.jpg)](/wiki/File:F-4B_VF-151_CV-41_TU-95.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:F-4B_VF-151_CV-41_TU-95.jpg "Enlarge")

United States Navy [F-4 Phantom II](/wiki/F-4_Phantom_II "F-4 Phantom II")
shadows a Soviet [Tu-95 Bear](/wiki/Tu-95_Bear "Tu-95 Bear") D aircraft in the
early 1970s

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Ed-Muskie-at-Earth-
Day-1970-web.jpg/200px-Ed-Muskie-at-Earth-Day-1970-web.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ed-
Muskie-at-Earth-Day-1970-web.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ed-Muskie-at-Earth-Day-1970-web.jpg "Enlarge")

U.S. Senator [Edmund Muskie](/wiki/Edmund_Muskie "Edmund Muskie") speaking at
Fairmount Park, Philadelphia on Earth Day, 1970

Amid the Cold War, the United States entered the [Vietnam
War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War"), whose growing unpopularity fed already
existing social movements, including those among women, minorities, and young
people. President [Lyndon B. Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B.
Johnson")'s [Great Society](/wiki/Great_Society "Great Society") social
programs and numerous rulings by the [Warren Court](/wiki/Warren_Court "Warren
Court") added to the wide range of [social reform](/wiki/Social_reform "Social
reform") during the 1960s and 1970s. [Feminism](/wiki/Feminism "Feminism") and
the [environmental movement](/wiki/Environmental_movement "Environmental
movement") became political forces, and progress continued toward [civil
rights](/wiki/Civil_rights "Civil rights") for all Americans. The
[Counterculture Revolution](/wiki/Counterculture_of_the_1960s "Counterculture
of the 1960s") swept through the nation and much of the western world in the
late sixties and early seventies, further dividing Americans in a "culture
war" but also bringing forth more liberated social views.[200]

Johnson was succeeded in 1969 by Republican [Richard
Nixon](/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon"), who [attempted to gradually turn
the war over to](/wiki/Vietnamization "Vietnamization") the [South
Vietnamese](/wiki/South_Vietnamese "South Vietnamese") forces. He negotiated
the [peace treaty in 1973](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Accords "Paris Peace Accords")
which secured the release of POWs and led to the withdrawal of U.S. troops.
The war had cost the lives of 58,000 American troops. Nixon manipulated the
fierce distrust between the Soviet Union and China to the advantage of the
United States, achieving _[détente](/wiki/D%C3%A9tente "Détente")_
(relaxation; ease of tension) with both parties.[201]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Nixon-
depart.png/200px-Nixon-depart.png)](/wiki/File:Nixon-depart.png)

[](/wiki/File:Nixon-depart.png "Enlarge")

Nixon departs

The [Watergate scandal](/wiki/Watergate_scandal "Watergate scandal"),
involving Nixon's cover-up of his operatives' break-in into the [Democratic
National Committee](/wiki/Democratic_National_Committee "Democratic National
Committee") headquarters at the [Watergate office
complex](/wiki/Watergate_complex "Watergate complex") destroyed his political
base, sent many aides to prison, and forced Nixon's resignation on August 9,
1974. He was succeeded by Vice President [Gerald Ford](/wiki/Gerald_Ford
"Gerald Ford"). The [Fall of Saigon](/wiki/Fall_of_Saigon "Fall of Saigon")
ended the Vietnam War and resulted in North and South [Vietnam](/wiki/Vietnam
"Vietnam") being reunited. Communist victories in neighboring
[Cambodia](/wiki/Cambodia "Cambodia") and [Laos](/wiki/Laos "Laos") occurred
in the same year.[201]

The [OPEC oil embargo](/wiki/1973_oil_crisis "1973 oil crisis") marked a long-
term economic transition since, for the first time, energy prices skyrocketed,
and American factories faced serious competition from foreign automobiles,
clothing, electronics, and consumer goods. By the late 1970s the economy
suffered an [energy crisis](/wiki/1970s_Energy_Crisis "1970s Energy Crisis"),
slow economic growth, high unemployment, and very high inflation coupled with
high interest rates (the term [stagflation](/wiki/Stagflation "Stagflation")
was coined). Since economists agreed on the wisdom of
[deregulation](/wiki/Deregulation "Deregulation"), many of the New Deal era
regulations were ended, such as in transportation, banking, and
telecommunications.[202]

[Jimmy Carter](/wiki/Jimmy_Carter "Jimmy Carter"), running as someone who was
not a part of the Washington political establishment, was elected president in
1976.[203] On the world stage, Carter brokered the [Camp David
Accords](/wiki/Camp_David_Accords "Camp David Accords") between Israel and
Egypt. In 1979, Iranian students stormed the U.S. embassy in
[Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran") and took 66 Americans hostage, resulting in
the [Iran hostage crisis](/wiki/Iran_hostage_crisis "Iran hostage crisis").
With the hostage crisis and continuing stagflation, Carter lost the [1980
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1980 "United States
presidential election, 1980") to the Republican [Ronald
Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan").[204] On January 20, 1981,
minutes after Carter's term in office ended, the remaining U.S. captives held
at the U.S. embassy in Iran were released, ending the 444-day hostage
crisis.[205]

### Close of the 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=41
"Edit section: Close of the 20th century")]

Main article: [History of the United States

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/ReaganBerlinWall.jpg/220px-
ReaganBerlinWall.jpg)](/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ReaganBerlinWall.jpg "Enlarge")

[Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") at the [Brandenburg
Gate](/wiki/Brandenburg_Gate "Brandenburg Gate") challenges Soviet premier
[Mikhail Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev") to [tear
down](/wiki/Tear_down_this_wall "Tear down this wall") the [Berlin
Wall](/wiki/Berlin_Wall "Berlin Wall") in 1987, shortly before the end of the
[Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War").

[Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") produced a major
[realignment](/wiki/Realigning_election "Realigning election") with his
[1980](/wiki/U.S._presidential_election,_1980 "U.S. presidential election,
1980") and [1984](/wiki/U.S._presidential_election,_1984 "U.S. presidential
election, 1984") landslide elections. Reagan's economic policies (dubbed
"[Reaganomics](/wiki/Reaganomics "Reaganomics")") and the implementation of
the [Economic Recovery Tax Act of
1981](/wiki/Economic_Recovery_Tax_Act_of_1981 "Economic Recovery Tax Act of
1981") lowered the top marginal tax rate from 70% to 28% over the course of
seven years.[206] Reagan continued to downsize government taxation and
regulation.[207] The U.S. experienced a recession in 1982, but the negative
indicators reversed, with the inflation rate decreasing from 11% to 2%, the
unemployment rate decreasing from 10.8% in December 1982 to 7.5% in November
1984,[208] and the economic growth rate increasing from 4.5% to 7.2%.[209]

Reagan ordered a buildup of the U.S. military, incurring additional budget
deficits. Reagan introduced a complicated missile defense system known as the
[Strategic Defense Initiative](/wiki/Strategic_Defense_Initiative "Strategic
Defense Initiative") (SDI) (dubbed "Star Wars" by opponents) in which,
theoretically, the U.S. could shoot down missiles with laser systems in space.
The Soviets reacted harshly because they thought it violated the 1972 [Anti-
Ballistic Missile Treaty](/wiki/Anti-Ballistic_Missile_Treaty "Anti-Ballistic
Missile Treaty"), and would upset the balance of power by giving the U.S. a
major military advantage. For years Soviet leader [Mikhail
Gorbachev](/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev "Mikhail Gorbachev") argued vehemently
against SDI. However, by the late 1980s he decided the system would never work
and should not be used to block disarmament deals with the U.S.[210]
Historians argue how great an impact the SDI threat had on the Soviets –
whether it was enough to force Gorbachev to initiate radical reforms, or
whether the deterioration of the Soviet economy alone forced the reforms.
There is agreement that the Soviets realized they were well behind the
Americans in military technology, that to try to catch up would be very
expensive, and that the military expenses were already a very heavy burden
slowing down their economy.[211]

Reagan's [Invasion of Grenada](/wiki/Invasion_of_Grenada "Invasion of
Grenada") and [bombing of Libya](/wiki/1986_United_States_bombing_of_Libya
"1986 United States bombing of Libya") were popular in the U.S, though his
backing of the [Contras](/wiki/Contras "Contras") rebels was mired in the
controversy over the [Iran–Contra affair](/wiki/Iran%E2%80%93Contra_affair
"Iran–Contra affair") that revealed Reagan's poor management style.[212]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/President_Reagan_and_Sandra_Day_O%27Connor.jpg/220px-
President_Reagan_and_Sandra_Day_O%27Connor.jpg)](/wiki/File:President_Reagan_and_Sandra_Day_O%27Connor.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:President_Reagan_and_Sandra_Day_O%27Connor.jpg "Enlarge")

Supreme Court Justice-nominee [Sandra Day
O'Connor](/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor "Sandra Day O'Connor") talks with
President [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") outside the
[White House](/wiki/White_House "White House"), July 15, 1981. Serving from
her appointment in 1981 by [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald
Reagan") until her retirement in 2006. She was the first woman to serve as a
Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.[213]

Reagan met four times with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev, who ascended to
power in 1985, and their summit conferences led to the signing of the
[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty](/wiki/Intermediate-
Range_Nuclear_Forces_Treaty "Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty").
Gorbachev tried to save Communism in the Soviet Union first by ending the
expensive arms race with America,[214] then by shedding the East European
empire in 1989. The [Soviet Union
collapsed](/wiki/Dissolution_of_the_Soviet_Union "Dissolution of the Soviet
Union") on [Christmas Day](/wiki/Christmas "Christmas") 1991, ending the
U.S–Soviet [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8d/Reagan_and_Gorbachev_signing.jpg/250px-
Reagan_and_Gorbachev_signing.jpg)](/wiki/File:Reagan_and_Gorbachev_signing.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Reagan_and_Gorbachev_signing.jpg "Enlarge")

[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty](/wiki/Intermediate-
Range_Nuclear_Forces_Treaty "Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty")

The United States emerged as the world's sole remaining superpower and
continued to intervene in international affairs during the 1990s, including
the 1991 [Gulf War](/wiki/Gulf_War "Gulf War") against [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq
"Iraq"). Following [his election in
1992](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1992 "United States
presidential election, 1992"), President [Bill Clinton](/wiki/Bill_Clinton
"Bill Clinton") oversaw one of the longest periods of economic expansion and
unprecedented gains in securities values, a side effect of the [digital
revolution](/wiki/Digital_revolution "Digital revolution") and new business
opportunities created by the Internet. He also worked with the Republican
Congress to pass the first balanced federal budget in 30 years.[215]

In 1998, [Clinton was impeached](/wiki/Impeachment_of_Bill_Clinton
"Impeachment of Bill Clinton") by the House of Representatives on charges of
lying about a sexual relationship with White House intern [Monica
Lewinsky](/wiki/Monica_Lewinsky "Monica Lewinsky"). He was acquitted by the
Senate. The failure of impeachment and the Democratic gains in the 1998
election forced House Speaker [Newt Gingrich](/wiki/Newt_Gingrich "Newt
Gingrich"), a Republican, to resign from Congress.[215]

Bill_Clinton%2C_Yitzhak_Rabin%2C_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bill_Clinton,_Yitzhak_Rabin,_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bill_Clinton,_Yitzhak_Rabin,_Yasser_Arafat_at_the_White_House_1993-09-13.jpg
"Enlarge")

Clinton, [Yitzhak Rabin](/wiki/Yitzhak_Rabin "Yitzhak Rabin") and [Yasser
Arafat](/wiki/Yasser_Arafat "Yasser Arafat") during the [Oslo
Accords](/wiki/Oslo_Accords "Oslo Accords") on September 13, 1993.

The Republican Party expanded its base throughout the South after 1968
(excepting 1976), largely due to its strength among [socially
conservative](/wiki/Social_conservatism "Social conservatism") white
Evangelical Protestants and traditionalist Roman Catholics, added to its
traditional strength in the business community and suburbs. As white Democrats
in the South lost dominance of the Democratic Party in the 1990s, the region
took on the [two-party](/wiki/Two-party_system "Two-party system") apparatus
which characterized most of the nation. The Republican Party's central leader
by 1980 was [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan"), whose
[conservative](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the
United States") policies called for reduced government spending and
regulation, lower taxes, and a strong anti-[Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet
Union") foreign policy. His iconic status in the party persists into the 21st
century, as practically all Republican Party leaders acknowledge his stature.
Social scientists Theodore Caplow et al. argue, "The Republican party,
nationally, moved from right-center toward the center in 1940s and 1950s, then
moved right again in the 1970s and 1980s." They add: "The Democratic party,
nationally, moved from left-center toward the center in the 1940s and 1950s,
then moved further toward the right-center in the 1970s and 1980s."[216]

The [presidential election in
2000](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2000 "United States
presidential election, 2000") between [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush
"George W. Bush") and [Al Gore](/wiki/Al_Gore "Al Gore") was one of the
closest in U.S. history and helped lay the seeds for political polarization to
come. The vote in the decisive state of Florida was extremely close and
produced a dramatic [dispute over the counting of
votes](/wiki/Florida_election_recount "Florida election recount"). The U.S.
Supreme Court in _[Bush v. Gore](/wiki/Bush_v._Gore "Bush v. Gore")_ ended the
recount with a 5–4 vote. That meant Bush, then in the lead, carried Florida
and the election.[217] Including 2000, the Democrats outpolled the Republicans
in the national vote in every election from 1992 to 2016, except for 2004.

### 9/11 and the War on
Terror[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=43
"Edit section: 9/11 and the War on Terror")]

Main article: [History of the United States

of the United States \(1991–2008\)")

Further information: [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks
"September 11 attacks") and [War on Terror](/wiki/War_on_Terror "War on
Terror")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Nasdaq_Composite_dot-
com_bubble.svg/300px-Nasdaq_Composite_dot-
com_bubble.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Nasdaq_Composite_dot-com_bubble.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Nasdaq_Composite_dot-com_bubble.svg "Enlarge")

The [NASDAQ Composite](/wiki/NASDAQ_Composite "NASDAQ Composite") index
swelled with the [dot-com bubble](/wiki/Dot-com_bubble "Dot-com bubble") in
the optimistic "[New Economy](/wiki/New_Economy "New Economy")". The bubble
burst in 2000.

On September 11, 2001 ("9/11"), the United States was struck by a [terrorist
attack](/wiki/Terrorism "Terrorism") when 19 [al-Qaeda](/wiki/Al-Qaeda "Al-
Qaeda") hijackers commandeered four airliners to be used in [suicide
attacks](/wiki/Suicide_attacks "Suicide attacks") and intentionally crashed
two into both twin towers of the [World Trade
Center](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_\(1973%E2%80%932001\) "World Trade Center
\(1973–2001\)") and the third into [the Pentagon](/wiki/The_Pentagon "The
Pentagon"), killing 2,937 victims—206 aboard the three airliners, 2,606 who
were in the World Trade Center and on the ground, and 125 who were in the
Pentagon.[218] The fourth plane was re-taken by the passengers and crew of the
aircraft. While they were not able to land the plane safely, they were able to
re-take control of the aircraft and crash it into an empty field in
Pennsylvania, killing all 44 people including the four terrorists on board,
thereby saving whatever target the terrorists were aiming for. Within two
hours, both Twin Towers of the World Trade Center completely collapsed causing
massive damage to the surrounding area and blanketing [Lower
Manhattan](/wiki/Lower_Manhattan "Lower Manhattan") in toxic dust clouds. All
in all, a total of 2,977 victims perished in the attacks. In response,
President [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") on September
20 announced a "War on Terror". On October 7, 2001, the United States and NATO
then [invaded Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%93present\)
"War in Afghanistan \(2001–present\)") to oust the [Taliban](/wiki/Taliban
"Taliban") regime, which had provided safe haven to al-Qaeda and its leader
[Osama bin Laden](/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden "Osama bin Laden").[219]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg/240px-
WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)](/wiki/File:WTC_smoking_on_9-11.jpeg)

The former [World Trade Center](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_\(1973%E2%80%932001\)
"World Trade Center \(1973–2001\)") in [Lower Manhattan](/wiki/Lower_Manhattan
"Lower Manhattan") during [September 11 attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks
"September 11 attacks") in 2001

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ac/OneWorldTradeCenter.jpg/120px-

[One World Trade Center](/wiki/One_World_Trade_Center "One World Trade

The federal government established new domestic efforts to prevent future
attacks. The controversial [USA PATRIOT Act](/wiki/USA_PATRIOT_Act "USA
PATRIOT Act") increased the government's power to monitor communications and
removed legal restrictions on information sharing between federal law
enforcement and intelligence services. A cabinet-level agency called the
[Department of Homeland
Security](/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Homeland_Security "United States
Department of Homeland Security") was created to lead and coordinate federal
[counter-terrorism](/wiki/Counter-terrorism "Counter-terrorism")
activities.[220] Some of these anti-terrorism efforts, particularly the U.S.
government's handling of detainees at the prison at [Guantanamo
Bay](/wiki/Guantanamo_Bay "Guantanamo Bay"), led to allegations against the
U.S. government of [human rights violations](/wiki/Human_rights_violations
"Human rights violations").[221][222]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Bush_2002_UNGA.jpg/220px-
Bush_2002_UNGA.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bush_2002_UNGA.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Bush_2002_UNGA.jpg "Enlarge")

[George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") addressed the [General
Assembly of the United Nations](/wiki/General_Assembly_of_the_United_Nations
"General Assembly of the United Nations") on 12 September 2002 to outline the
complaints of the United States government against the Iraqi government.

In 2003, from March 19 to May 1, the United States launched [an invasion of
Iraq](/wiki/2003_invasion_of_Iraq "2003 invasion of Iraq"), which led to the
collapse of the [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq") government and the eventual capture
of Iraqi dictator [Saddam Hussein](/wiki/Saddam_Hussein "Saddam Hussein"),
with whom the U.S. had long-standing tense relations. The reasons for the
invasion cited by the Bush administration included the spreading of democracy,
the elimination of [weapons of mass
destruction](/wiki/Weapons_of_mass_destruction "Weapons of mass
destruction")[223] (a key demand of the UN as well, though later
investigations found parts of the intelligence reports to be inaccurate),[224]
and the liberation of the Iraqi people. Despite some initial successes early
in the invasion, the continued [Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War") fueled
[international protests](/wiki/Protests_against_the_Iraq_War "Protests against
the Iraq War") and gradually saw [domestic support
decline](/wiki/Popular_opinion_in_the_United_States_on_the_invasion_of_Iraq
"Popular opinion in the United States on the invasion of Iraq") as many people
began to question whether or not the invasion was worth the cost.[225][226] In
2007, after years of violence by the [Iraqi
insurgency](/wiki/Iraqi_insurgency_\(Iraq_War\) "Iraqi insurgency \(Iraq
War\)"), President Bush deployed more troops in a strategy dubbed "[the
surge](/wiki/Iraq_War_troop_surge_of_2007 "Iraq War troop surge of 2007")".
While the death toll decreased, the political stability of Iraq remained in
doubt.[227]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Lehman_Brothers_Times_Square_by_David_Shankbone.jpg/250px-
Lehman_Brothers_Times_Square_by_David_Shankbone.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lehman_Brothers_Times_Square_by_David_Shankbone.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lehman_Brothers_Times_Square_by_David_Shankbone.jpg "Enlarge")

Headquarters of the [Lehman Brothers](/wiki/Lehman_Brothers "Lehman
Brothers"), who filed for bankruptcy in September 2008 at the height of the
U.S. [financial crisis](/wiki/Financial_crisis "Financial crisis").

In 2008, the unpopularity of President Bush and the Iraq war, along with the
[2008 financial crisis](/wiki/Financial_crisis_of_2007%E2%80%9308 "Financial
crisis of 2007–08"), led to the election of [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama
"Barack Obama"), the first [African-American](/wiki/African-American "African-
American") President of the United States.[228] After his election, Obama
reluctantly continued the war effort in Iraq until August 31, 2010, when he
declared that combat operations had ended. However, 50,000 American soldiers
and military personnel were kept in Iraq to assist Iraqi forces, help protect
withdrawing forces, and work on counter-terrorism until December 15, 2011,
when the war was declared formally over and the last troops [left the
country](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_U.S._troops_from_Iraq "Withdrawal of U.S. troops
from Iraq").[229] At the same time, Obama increased American involvement in
Afghanistan, starting a surge strategy using an additional 30,000 troops,
while proposing to begin [withdrawing
troops](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_U.S._troops_from_Afghanistan "Withdrawal of U.S.
troops from Afghanistan") sometime in December 2014. With regards to
Guantanamo Bay, President Obama forbade [torture](/wiki/Torture "Torture") but
in general retained Bush's policy regarding the Guantanamo detainees, while
also proposing that the prison eventually be closed.[230][231]

In May 2011, after nearly a decade in hiding, the founder and leader of Al
Qaeda, [Osama bin Laden](/wiki/Osama_bin_Laden "Osama bin Laden"), was killed
in Pakistan in a raid conducted by U.S. naval special forces acting under
President Obama's direct orders. While Al Qaeda was near collapse in
Afghanistan, affiliated organizations continued to operate in
[Yemen](/wiki/Yemen "Yemen") and other remote areas as the [CIA](/wiki/CIA
"CIA") used [drones](/wiki/Unmanned_Combat_Aerial_Vehicle "Unmanned Combat
Aerial Vehicle") to hunt down and remove its leadership.[232][233]

The Boston Marathon Bombing was a bombing incident, followed by subsequent
related shootings, that occurred when two pressure cooker bombs exploded
during the Boston Marathon on April 15, 2013. The bombs exploded about 12
seconds and 210 yards (190 m) apart at 2:49 pm EDT, near the marathon's finish
line on Boylston Street. They killed 3 people and injured an estimated 264
others.

The [Islamic State of Iraq and the
Levant](/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant "Islamic State of Iraq and
the Levant") – formerly known as Al-Qaeda in Iraq – rose to prominence in
September 2014. In addition to taking control of much of Western Iraq and
Eastern Syria, ISIS also beheaded three journalists, two American and one
British. These events lead to [a major military
offensive](/wiki/2014_military_intervention_against_the_Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant
"2014 military intervention against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant")
by the US and its allies in the region.

On December 28, 2014, President Obama officially ended the combat mission in
Afghanistan and promised a withdrawal of all remaining U.S. troops at the end
of 2016 with the exception of the embassy guards.[234]

### The Great
Recession[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=44
"Edit section: The Great Recession")]

Main article: [Great Recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Obama_meets_with_Congressional_Leadership_July_2011.jpg/250px-
Obama_meets_with_Congressional_Leadership_July_2011.jpg)](/wiki/File:Obama_meets_with_Congressional_Leadership_July_2011.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Obama_meets_with_Congressional_Leadership_July_2011.jpg
"Enlarge")

Congressional leadership meeting with then-President Obama in 2011.

In September 2008, the United States, and most of Europe, entered the longest
post–World War II [recession](/wiki/Recession "Recession"), often called the
"Great Recession."[235][236] Multiple overlapping crises were involved,
especially the [housing market
crisis](/wiki/United_States_housing_market_correction "United States housing
market correction"), a [subprime mortgage
crisis](/wiki/Subprime_mortgage_crisis "Subprime mortgage crisis"), [soaring
oil prices](/wiki/2000s_energy_crisis "2000s energy crisis"), an [automotive
industry
crisis](/wiki/Effects_of_the_2008%E2%80%9310_automotive_industry_crisis_on_the_United_States
"Effects of the 2008–10 automotive industry crisis on the United States"),
rising unemployment, and the worst [financial crisis](/wiki/Financial_crisis
"Financial crisis") since the [Great Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great
Depression"). The financial crisis threatened the stability of the entire
economy in September 2008 when [Lehman Brothers](/wiki/Lehman_Brothers "Lehman
Brothers") failed and other giant banks were in grave danger.[237] Starting in
October the federal government lent $245 billion to financial institutions
through the [Troubled Asset Relief
Program](/wiki/Troubled_Asset_Relief_Program "Troubled Asset Relief
Program")[238] which was passed by bipartisan majorities and signed by
Bush.[239]

Following his election victory by a wide electoral margin in [November
2008](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2008 "United States
presidential election, 2008"), Bush's successor – [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") – signed into law the [American
Recovery and Reinvestment Act of
2009](/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009 "American Recovery
and Reinvestment Act of 2009"), which was a $787 billion economic stimulus
aimed at helping the economy recover from the deepening recession. Obama, like
Bush, took steps to rescue the auto industry and prevent future economic
meltdowns. These included a bailout of [General Motors](/wiki/General_Motors
"General Motors") and [Chrysler](/wiki/Chrysler "Chrysler"), putting ownership
temporarily in the hands of the government, and the "[cash for
clunkers](/wiki/Cash_for_clunkers "Cash for clunkers")" program which
temporarily boosted new car sales.[240]

The recession officially ended in June 2009, and the economy slowly began to
expand once again.[241] The unemployment rate peaked at 10.1% in October 2009
after surging from 4.7% in November 2007, and returned to 5.0% as of October
2015. However, overall economic growth has remained weaker in the 2010s
compared to expansions in previous decades.[242][243][244]

### Recent
events[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=45

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/d8/TeaPartyByFreedomFan.JPG/250px-

From 2009 to 2010, the [111th Congress](/wiki/111th_United_States_Congress
"111th United States Congress") passed major legislation such as the [Patient
Protection and Affordable Care
Act](/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient Protection and
Affordable Care Act"), informally known as Obamacare, the [Dodd–Frank Wall
Street Reform and Consumer Protection
Act](/wiki/Dodd%E2%80%93Frank_Wall_Street_Reform_and_Consumer_Protection_Act
"Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act")[245] and the
[Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act](/wiki/Don%27t_Ask,_Don%27t_Tell_Repeal_Act
"Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act"), which were signed into law by President
Obama.[246] Following the [2010 midterm
elections](/wiki/United_States_elections,_2010 "United States elections,
2010"), which resulted in a Republican-controlled House of Representatives and
a Democratic-controlled Senate,[247] Congress presided over a period of
elevated gridlock and heated debates over whether or not to raise the [debt
ceiling](/wiki/Debt_ceiling "Debt ceiling"), extend tax cuts for citizens
making over $250,000 annually, and many other key issues.[248] These ongoing
debates led to President Obama signing the [Budget Control Act of
2011](/wiki/Budget_Control_Act_of_2011 "Budget Control Act of 2011"). In the
Fall of 2012, [Mitt Romney](/wiki/Mitt_Romney "Mitt Romney") challenged Barack
Obama for the Presidency. Following Obama's reelection in November 2012,
Congress passed the [American Taxpayer Relief Act of
2012](/wiki/American_Taxpayer_Relief_Act_of_2012 "American Taxpayer Relief Act
of 2012") – which resulted in an increase in taxes primarily on those earning
the most money. Congressional gridlock continued as Congressional Republicans'
call for the repeal of the [Patient Protection and Affordable Care
Act](/wiki/Patient_Protection_and_Affordable_Care_Act "Patient Protection and
Affordable Care Act") – popularly known as "Obamacare" – along with other
various demands, resulted in the [first government shutdown since the Clinton
administration](/wiki/2013_United_States_government_shutdown "2013 United
States government shutdown") and almost led to the first default on [U.S.
debt](/wiki/U.S._debt "U.S. debt") since the 19th century. As a result of
growing public frustration with both parties in Congress since the beginning
of the decade, Congressional approval ratings fell to record lows, with only
11% of Americans approving as of October 2013.[249]

Other major events that have occurred during the 2010s include the rise of new
political movements, such as the
[conservative](/wiki/Conservatism_in_the_United_States "Conservatism in the
United States") [Tea Party movement](/wiki/Tea_Party_movement "Tea Party
movement") and the [liberal](/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States
"Modern liberalism in the United States") [Occupy
movement](/wiki/Occupy_movement "Occupy movement"). There was also unusually
severe weather during the early part of the decade. In 2012, over half the
country experienced record drought and [Hurricane Sandy](/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy
"Hurricane Sandy") caused massive damage to coastal areas of New York and New
Jersey.

The ongoing debate over the issue of rights for [the LGBT
community](/wiki/LGBT_in_the_United_States "LGBT in the United States"), most
notably that of [same-sex marriage](/wiki/Same-sex_marriage "Same-sex
marriage"), began to shift in favor of same-sex couples, and has been
reflected in dozens of polls released in the early part of the decade.[250] In
2012, President Obama became the first president to openly support same-sex
marriage, and the 2013 [Supreme
Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") decision in the case of [United States v.
Windsor](/wiki/United_States_v._Windsor "United States v. Windsor") provided
for federal recognition of same-sex unions. In June 2015, the Supreme Court
legalized gay marriage nationally in the case of _[Obergefell v.
Hodges](/wiki/Obergefell_v._Hodges "Obergefell v. Hodges")_.

Political debate has continued over issues such as [tax
reform](/wiki/Tax_reform "Tax reform"), [immigration
reform](/wiki/Immigration_reform "Immigration reform"), [income
inequality](/wiki/Income_inequality "Income inequality") and U.S. foreign
policy in the [Middle East](/wiki/Middle_East "Middle East"), particularly
with regards to [global terrorism](/wiki/Terrorism "Terrorism"), the rise of
the [Islamic State of Iraq and the
Levant](/wiki/Islamic_State_of_Iraq_and_the_Levant "Islamic State of Iraq and
the Levant") and an accompanying climate of [Islamophobia](/wiki/Islamophobia
"Islamophobia").[251]

On November 8, 2016, Republican Party presidential nominee [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") defeated Democratic nominee [Hillary
Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton") to become the President-
elect of the United States.[252] Trump's election became mired in controversy
after U.S. intelligence agencies concluded that associates of the
[Russian](/wiki/Russia "Russia") government [interfered in the
election](/wiki/Russian_interference_in_the_2016_United_States_elections
"Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections") "to undermine
public faith in the U.S. democratic process." This, along with questions about
potential collusion between the Trump campaign and Russian officials, led to
the launch of investigations into the matter by the FBI, and the
[Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate_Select_Committee_on_Intelligence "United
States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence") and the [House Intelligence
Committees](/wiki/United_States_House_Permanent_Select_Committee_on_Intelligence
"United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence").[253][254]
